PETITION.TITLE: Drug Usage
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth; that we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life particularly by increased penalties for ``drug pushers'' and distributors. We, however, wish to register our firm opposition to any legal changes which would increase or encourage the distribution or availability of so-called ``soft drugs'' such as marijuana. We believe such drugs to be harmful to the physical and psychological health of the individual and therefore to the interest of the community of which such individual is part. Although there is current controversy concerning the question of such harm it appears to us quite foolish to legalise and encourage the use of such drugs unless or until it be shown that such drugs are in fact harmless. The serious social problems of alcohol should provide sufficient warning to our society.
Any efforts to legalise or decriminalise usage or distribution of such drugs will have the following results:
1. Encourage and inculcate a social acceptability towards such drugs.
2. Increase the volume of usage of such drugs in schools and the community by present users and by ``drug pushers'' through the proposed one ounce legal possession.
3. Extend the usage of such drugs to persons who would previously have abstained because of the legal sanctions.

4. Put pressure upon Parliament to establish and license imports, growth, manufacture and/or distribution of such drugs, that is, to regulate another destructive industry contrary to the best interest of the individual and society.
5. There would be probable temptation to tax such drugs as another source of Federal revenue.

We urge the Government to increase the medical and counselling facilities for the assistance of drug users and to expand existing Drug Referral Centres and Clinics. We have general confidence in the existing law and its sympathetic implementation by the Police and Courts.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will firstly take no measures that could extend the major social problem of drug usage and secondly will oblige those who are promoting marijuana and/or similar drugs to prove without doubt that such drugs are harmless before any legalisation or decriminalisation of use is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some questions about this Ordinance that have been answered by the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) but I think we will have to agree to disagree. SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Senator B Cooney
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA, ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney

Thank you for your letter of 10 October 1986, in which you have expressed concern about a strict liability imposed on members of Boards of ACT credit societies who contravene the provisions of section 14g of the ACT Co-operative Societies Ordinance, introduced by the Co-operative Societies (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1986 (No. 10 of 1986).

It appears that the interpretation of section 14 set out in your letter may have overlooked some parts of the new section 14g. Sub-sections 14g (1f) and (1g) place percentage of value limits on credit societies' loans. However these do not operate to make directors of the society liable for a loss occasioned simply by a decline, after the advance is made, in the market value of land. Such a liability would not arise in any case, whether of a decline in value or an initial overestimate, where the directors acted bona fide, and on a valuation given by an approved valuer within three months before the advance, in lending funds up to the prescribed maximum limit. This is because in these circumstances the `value' of the land of which sub-sections (1f) and (1g) speak is defined as the `value' given in the valuation report, not the actual value: see sub-section (1j).

The only circumstances in which a loss would be likely to involve liability under sub-section (1h) are where the directors acted without first obtaining a valuation report, or advanced more than the prescribed percentage of the value reported to them. In either case, even if the debt went bad immediately and completely, the directors would be liable for 10% at most, or, if mortgage insurance were obtained, 5% at most, of the loss.

I do not think it unreasonable to impose such a liability. There is no statutory reserve fund for credit societies in the ACT, and the Government is not their lender of last resort as in the case of banks. I consider, therefore, that strict controls on the management of credit societies are necessary to secure the paramount policy objective of the Co-operative Societies Ordinance, the protection of societies' members. Indeed, provisions similar to section 14g already apply to building societies in the ACT and to building societies and credit unions in New South Wales. I understand that these provisions are not considered too onerous by the directors of these institutions, and that the risk of loss to the institutions is avoided by mortgage insurance.
Yours sincerely
GORDON SCHOLES

But at the same time, in another piece of legislation which we will shortly be debating in this place, the Government in its Foreign Takeovers Amendment Bill is moving to reduce controls on foreign ownership of our resources. In the legislation before us the Government is shedding crocodile tears about our oil resources falling into foreign hands and in another piece of legislation it is lifting restrictions on the foreign ownership of our resources. These are absolutely contradictory government policies. Which one are we to take as the one that the Government really wants to happen, or does it want two contradictory policies to operate simultaneously?

SPEECH.PARA: In the words of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Government is moving to internationalise the Australian economy. One can only assume that the Government means that it wants to lift all restrictions to foreign capital and foreign money markets in their operations in Australia. No doubt it also means that it is seeking to encourage at rock bottom prices the buying up of our national estate, our resources, our wealth producing industries, our minerals and our farm land. That is a great tragedy because it is the policy that has been pursued by various governments over the last 20 to 30 years, a policy that is now in disarray. We have not got sufficient of our estate left to sell to buy our way out of debt; we have to work our way out of debt. The sooner we face up to that reality, the better. We have to export; we have to stop selling off our resources and stop buying luxury imports which we can no longer afford.

In the Government's taxing policy, which is what this legislation is all about, the Government has not shrunk from imposing additional hardships on the poor and the less well off while not imposing similar hardships on the wealthy and the foreign interests that operate in this country. The bank account debits tax, which this legislation increases, is a very good example of what I am saying. As an amendment in respect of the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill 1986, I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill. These Bills form part of a fairly large package of what the Government is trying to pass off to the Australian people as a package of tax reform or tax relief. The Government is trying to hoodwink the Australian people that it is embarking upon a lowering of the great tax rate burden. That is rather surprising, because one of the Bills before the Senate at the moment actually increases tax quite substantially. The other Bill-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3)-is really an omnibus Bill which contains a number of wide-ranging changes thrown into the taxation pot, again to try to hoodwink the people. Why, therefore, is it necessary to spend $2m in advertising revenue to sell this sort of package? I do not believe that the Australian people will have the wool pulled over their eyes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill will increase the general rate of bank account debits. The highest debit tax will be increased from $1.50 to $2, with other rates being increased by up to one half. These new rates will apply from 1 December this year. In effect, this is a straight tax increase which will bring the Government an additional $90m in revenue in a full year. The tax is yet another burden on Australian taxpayers. Extra payments will be made by individuals, both directly through their bank accounts and via increased charges made in the community due to additional costs which will be imposed on business.

At this stage it is appropriate to comment on the suggestion of the Australian Democrats of imposing a very significant 0.5 per cent charge on all debit transactions irrespective of their magnitude. This would really cut the finance industry to tatters because it is a massive increase that the finance community, the business community, would have to bear. The increase in the legislation before the Senate is really only one of many imposts that the present Labor Government has quietly slipped into place while declaring to Australia how it has been bravely battling a cumbersome taxation system. This is just another example of the hypocrisy going on on the taxation debate. The Australian Labor Party would have us believe that its new Budget strategy is here to save us. But since 1983 the Government has increased the taxation burden dramatically. In fact, revenue from the tax take has increased by 61 per cent in only four years of economic mismanagement by this failing Labor Government. This Labor Government is the highest taxing government in the history of Australia, raising 25.5 per cent of gross national product in taxes and, I add, breaking yet another of its election promises in the process.

The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1986, an omnibus Bill, incorporates a wide range of measures thrown up by the Government under the heading of taxation reform. Some of these measures are long overdue and some of them are really reversals of earlier decisions made by the Hawke Government that have been miserable failures. The Bill includes changes to the valuation of horses for income tax trading stock purposes. Fortunately, the Government did not proceed with a similar sort of valuation applying to sheep and cattle. I acknowledge its wisdom in backing down from that.

The Bill includes provisions covering the Defence Force reservists. It also authorises deductions in respect of cash bids for off-shore petroleum exploration permits. It amends the income tax laws to provide for the calculation of 1986-87 provisional tax. It also makes various changes to the taxation arrangements made with the Netherlands and Austria.

One of the amendments before us today concerns the reinstatement of full tax exemption for the pay and allowances of members of the Australian Defence Force Reserve. This change is long overdue. One could say that in some respects it is rather a case of shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted. When the Labor Government came to power in 1983, the Army reservists totalled 33,000. In the space of three years that number has plummeted by over 10,000-a virtual exodus from the reserve forces. Paul Dibb, in his review of the Australian defence capabilities, saw the reserve forces as instrumental in the defence of this vast country. The big downturn in numbers occurred when the Government removed the full tax exemption from the pay of reserve forces. That entitlement had operated for almost 20 years for the purpose of providing a degree of incentive to individuals of a high standard to join the reserve forces. The sort of people whom the reservists want to attract are those in civilian life who are probably paying fairly high rates of marginal tax. If their payments as reservists are to be taxed at this high rate, there is really little monetary reward for their sacrificing leisure hours to join the Reserve.

The result of the Government's decision to tax reservists' pay has been disastrous. The years of effort taken to build up reserve forces to a decent size has been destroyed by this Hawke Government after such a few years in office. When the number of reservists began to decline sharply in 1984, nothing was really done to rectify the situation. No amount of advertising by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in 1985 could buoy up the flagging morale of the Army reserves. Only now, when the damage has already been done, has the Government finally decided to try to patch up some of the problems. However, the road back to really restoring the effective strength of the reserves will be a long one and will not be an easy task for the Army. I believe the re-establishment of the tax exemption on pay is at least a step in the right direction.

Another change that this Bill will introduce concerns the valuation of new horses for income tax trading purposes. The existing law allows livestock on hand at the end of the year to be valued according to various criteria such as the cost price, the current market price or at some other value depending on the circumstances. There are minimum prescribed limits that are generally lower than actual value. This measure allows tax to be deferred until disposal. But the Bill before the Senate today actually makes it obligatory for horse breeders to value foals when they are born at the cost of the service fee, and the tax will be paid on that sum in that year. So, in effect, horse breeders have been singled out in this instance, as they are deemed to be dealing in livestock which is generally of greater value than that of other stock breeders. In the second reading speech, the Acting Treasurer, Mr Hurford, stated that the measure reflects the fact that the tax deferral advantages are much greater for horse breeders and that the new tax arrangements would only apply in respect of service fees. Such a tax will raise an estimated $7m in revenue in 1988-89, although it is interesting to note that the gains after that date will be fairly negligible. The fact that these gains will only be made when the tax is first brought in reveals the nature of this latest move by the Government. So the levy is in effect a forward tax; it is another means by which the Government can raise revenue for the coming year and present a Budget deficit which is artificially lower than it is in actuality. Such practices, I believe, expose the Government's production of a reduced deficit as something of a sham. It is a one-off type situation which leaves the Government nowhere to go in the future.

Another of the items dealt with by this Bill highlights, I believe, the mismanagement that this country has suffered under three years of the Hawke Labor Government. I refer to the revocation of the interest withholding tax, which was introduced initially earlier this year. An amendment in relation to interest withholding tax is being made to correct what proved to be a miscalculation of sizable proportion on the part of the Government. On 1 July the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the decision to remove the exemption from interest withholding tax that previously applied to individuals who had overseas securities and to government authorities with rollovers and extensions of loans. Such an ill-timed move illustrated the ineptitude of the Hawke Labor Government. Only 28 days after this tax was introduced the value of the dollar had fallen by about 6c. The Treasurer was then forced to make a quick about-turn decision on this latest impost. Not only did this fiasco have an immediate detrimental effect on our money markets, but also it served to undermine the confidence of the overseas investors in Australia. I think it also showed the inability of the Government to run the economy and government successfully.

On a more positive note, I must actually applaud the Government's decision to make donations of the value of $2 or more to the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and to the Australian College of Occupational Medicine tax deductible under section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Of course, these deductions will apply after 19 August 1986. The encouragement of research and development in Australia, as has often been said in this place, is extremely important to the future direction of this country. We all believe that industry, government and the scientific community must collaborate if Australia is to lift its export earnings in technology based goods and services. Otherwise, our hopes of becoming competitive will be delusions. Our export opportunities can only be realised by undertaking more research, more quality control and more marketing. I think industry has recognised that quality control, obviously, is more than just a person standing at the end of a production line. The development of the Australian economy of late has been based unfortunately on the exploitation solely of our natural resources. There has been little downstream manufacturing production using those natural resources. So for the main part our manufacturing industries have tended to be absent from world markets and our technological base has remained unchanged for 30-odd years. However, on the other side of the coin since the Hawke Government has come to power, Federal funding for science has decreased by 9.2 per cent in real terms. At least the concession before us, however minor, is a positive step towards promoting research and development in Australia and to stem the loss of our scientific talent to overseas.

The legislation involves a great deal of complication and it is time the Government moved to simplify the calculation of provisional tax. The Bill's provisions are bewildering to the ordinary citizen and indicate more and more that rather than moving towards tax reform, we are moving towards tax complication. The provisions for the calculation of provisional tax in this Bill are not a move to the right direction, but will put more and more people into the hands of tax accountants to prepare tax returns. I believe that this whole package of measures must be condemned. The package includes the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, and for ordinary Australian taxpayers these are the unintended consequences or this is unintended legislation so far as those people who voted the Hawke Labor Government into power, because these measures were not part of the election package that was put before the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Watson said, to an extent this package of Bills-the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill-corrects mistakes made by the Government. As he also correctly said, they are part of a package of tax measures which will massively increase the tax burden on Australians, even after taking into account the tax cuts promised for 1 December. Those tax cuts were supposed to have operated from September, but they were deferred in yet another breach of undertaking by this Government. This has made this Government the least reliable in Australia's history in breaking commitments given to the people at elections. We all know about the breach in respect of the capital gains tax, and so it goes across a whole range of activities, particularly affecting retired people, the aged of our nation. But let us recognise that this particular group of Bills in net form reduces marginally the tax burden, which is being massively increased under the package introduced in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: We must recognise that this package of Bills was supposed to be the bribe in order to get a real and major reform of the Australian tax system. It was a bribe offered to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and others in order that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) could get what I believed to be a sensible alteration to the incidence of taxation by changing the proportion of personal income tax collected as a result of increasing the indirect tax base. That was directly in line with Opposition policy, which is different in only one respect from the Treasurer's attempted and failed policy of this score. Our essential difference is that it is primary in our tax approach that the total taxation burden be reduced because Government spending should be reduced. But within that framework we had further wanted to reduce the incidence of personal income tax and we presented this policy in the 1984 election. We wanted to make that reduction by increasing the share of tax revenues made up by indirect taxes. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, shared that part of the Opposition's policy which involved diminishing the personal income tax share but increasing the indirect tax share. Of course he failed to support the proposition, which is central to our approach to tax, that the total taxation burden should be reduced by cutting government spending. In any event, his attempts were defeated and these Bills before us today are part of the bribe that was offered to the ACTU and others to support the Treasurer's sensible attempts-attempts that were sabotaged by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who met with ACTU leaders in a secret meeting in a hotel room in Canberra-to introduce major taxation reforms. All that is left now is the bribe and none of the substance of the taxation reform. To pretend that these Bills and this package are part of some major taxation reform, as the Government is doing, is to bend the truth in an extraordinary way. We are left with the bribe to the left wing, without the benefits that should have emerged from that taxation reform attempt which was sabotaged by the Prime Minister.

As a result of that sabotage we now see something like an $800m burden being imposed, generally on the business community, and that will go a large part of the way towards paying for the tax cuts that the Government has tried to make so much of in political terms in recent weeks. Those tax cuts are being funded largely by increasing the burden on the Australian business community. That increased burden will not be suffered only by the business community because those businesses which do not go broke will be obliged to pass on the burden in higher costs or in reduced employment brought about by a cutting of their own costs. That means that this tax package will have an impact-and is having an impact-on levels of employment throughout Australia. In other words, the Government, by its own actions in the tax area, by seeking to make political gain, has brought about a negative impact on employment and is causing the loss of jobs and a reduction in the level of activity in the private sector which is so vital to get Australia out of the economic hole it is in.

To demonstrate this I point out that the Budget figures reveal that income tax collections from individuals are estimated to grow by 12.2 per cent in 1986-87. This is the year in which we are supposed to have the tax cuts, including the cuts involved in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1986. How can the Government pretend that it is easing the tax burden and how can it go around talking about taxation cuts when the total tax burden on individuals will increase by 12.2 per cent this year? That is an increase to a record level-the worst level of tax burden that this nation has ever had to wear and it is coming from the Government this year, despite all the talk about tax cuts. On top of that, as Senator Messner mentioned earlier, there is the additional immense administrative burden involved in this Government's whole approach to tax and in the measures we have been debating in this package. For example, this present package includes a reversal, as Senator Watson pointed out, of the interest withholding tax arrangements. That involves expense and inconvenience to the business community.

TALK.START.PARA: —That marked the turning point of loss of confidence.

—As Senator Watson says, that marked the turning point following which there was a loss of confidence. But on top of that, there are massive administrative costs in collecting the other taxes that are a part of this package although they may be not specifically in this Bill. I refer in particular to the fringe benefits tax. Through our questions to Commonwealth departments affected by this tax package, the Senate has been informed of the enormous administrative costs they will face. Departmental employees will have to spend hours and hours at public expense working out how much money to take out of the Government's right hand pocket in order to put it into its left hand pocket. It is most arrant nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: Another example of ineptitude, another mistake that is corrected in this specific legislation, concerns taxing the pay and allowances of the Defence Force Reserve. We opposed the Government when it introduced this tax last year. We said that it was nonsensical and a ridiculous thing to do; it was unfair, mean and damaging. This stupid decision was costing the Government far more in terms of the expense involved in trying to encourage more people to become members of the Reserve because its present members were leaving in droves. The Government can take the credit for that enormous turnover, for that enormous collapse. As a result, it set out on a $2m advertising campaign to correct the fact that people were leaving the Army Reserve. It had to try to encourage more people to join. Think of the enormous waste of training people at great length, at great expense, to be members of the Army Reserve, only to have them leave and then have to train more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who got the publicity value out of it?

—I am glad Senator Messner makes that point. The $2m campaign to encourage people to join the Army Reserve, to make up for the fact that so many reservists were voting with their feet on their confidence in this Government, had two significant elements. The second element of this advertising campaign was that, basically, it was a free publicity stunt for the Leader of the Australian Labor Party, the Prime Minister of Australia, whose face appeared in all those advertisements and who got immense personal public promotion at taxpayers' expense in a $2m advertising campaign. This is part of the pattern of public relations instead of decent government that goes on under this Prime Minister and this Labor Government; $2m spent because the Government, through its stupidity last year, had withdrawn the tax exempt status of reservists' pay. The Government has now recognised that stupidity and has recognised that, even after spending $2m, it is still behind in its recruitment. As a result it is being forced to backtrack and recognise that it was wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: If we go through previous legislation we see evidence all over the place of where this Government is admitting that it was wrong and where it is having to review things. Look at the fringe benefits tax. It is now reviewing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another $2m is to be spent promoting it.

—As the honourable senator has said, another $2m is to be spent promoting that. I bet that we will not have the Prime Minister's face all over the fringe benefits tax advertisement. There is no way that the Prime Minister's face will appear in advertisements stating what a wonderful thing the fringe benefits tax is. It will be the poor old Australian Taxation Office. We might find a photograph of an officer from the Taxation Office into which people can stick pins or which they can put up on dart boards but we will not find the Prime Minister's face on advertisements stating what a wonderful thing the fringe benefits tax is.

SPEECH.PARA: So here we have the hypocrisy, the double standards and the incompetence of this Government reflected in these tax measures. There is nothing new about that incompetence, there is nothing new about that hypocrisy and there is nothing new about those double standards. They have been with us ever since this Government came into office. We have seen it again and again. I suppose that the sort of backtracking involved in the legislation before us today is simply a recognition by some members of the Government that there will be political damage if they do not correct some of their mistakes. The current inquiry into the fringe benefits tax fiasco is all about the unintended consequences. The Government claims that it is making only administrative corrections. The points that have been pressed on this Government and the things worrying the Australian public are not simply administrative matters relating to the fringe benefits tax and other taxes in this whole package-they are fundamental to the taxes themselves. These unintended consequences are there because the tax law that this government has passed is defective. The fringe benefits tax and other taxes were passed with the support, the assistance and the connivance of the Australian Democrats. Let the Australian people never forget that.

I simply conclude by saying that, no doubt, we will see many more examples of this Government coming into the Senate producing more of these withdrawals, more of these corrections and more of these admissions of incompetence. The tax Bill which is before us today is simply one of the many and growing number of admissions that this Government does not know what it is doing, that it cannot handle matters effectively, that under its control the Australian economy has been falling apart and that the whole tax burden is being imposed, particularly on the business community, in such a way that it is damaging our prospects of economic recovery, destroying incentive and playing a significant role in the nation's inability at this stage to get itself out of this mess and out of the hole that the Treasurer has dug for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 8, after clause 19, insert the following clause:
Losses and outgoings
19a. Section 51 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end the following sub-section:
`(5) A deduction is not allowable under sub-section (1) in respect of expenditure for the purpose of the advertising or promotion of-
(a) tobacco, substances containing tobacco, synthetic tobacco or any substance intended or designed for smoking;
(b) cigarettes, cigars or other items intended or designed to be used for smoking; or
(c) smoking pipes or any other accessories, items or devices intended or designed to be used principally for or in association with smoking.'.

The amendment seeks to disallow as taxation deductions advertising and promotional activities associated with the tobacco industry. The wording is quite specifically aimed at the smoking problem, which the Better Health Commission says is the major preventable cause of premature death and disease in Australia today. There is just no reason at all why the pushers of tobacco, because they are corporations, should have virtually half their advertising and promotional costs-some 46 per cent-rebated by the community. This is particularly so in the light of the resolution which this Government successfully co-sponsored at the World Health Assembly in May 1986. The report of the National Health and Medical Research Council on passive smoking goes into this in some detail. The resolution recognises that tobacco smoking and the use of tobacco in all its forms is incompatible with the attainment of health for all by the year 2000. The resolution urges:

. . . those member states which have not yet done so to implement smoking control strategies . . . to ensure that non-smokers receive effective protection, to which they are entitled, from involuntary exposure to tobacco smoke in enclosed public places, restaurants, transport and places of work and entertainment.

We are making some progress towards cutting out smoking in the Public Service through the creation of smoke-free zones, but there seems no reason at all why the taxpayers should continue to subsidise this habit which is killing vast numbers of Australian each year. Basically that is what a tax deduction for tobacco promotion is. It not only promotes this kind of habit, but it also hits at very young people. The most effective way of attaining health for all by the year 2000 is to make the young people of this country immune to the deceitful blandishments of the pushers of tobacco. Part of that aim can be achieved by using examples of young people who are winners in their field and who have no truck with drugs of this type. We have seen the type of tactics tobacco companies use. This was brought to our attention at Question Time yesterday when Senator Peter Baume asked a question of Senator Grimes and they both agreed that the type of advertising being carried on by the tobacco companies was quite unethical. There is no reason why we should continue to subsidise this from the public purse.

Another means of achieving our goal is to put tobacco virtually out of the economic reach of youngsters. Even if the cost of promotion goes on to the tobacco, we will raise the price of this commodity and, hopefully, put it out of the reach of youngsters. We know that more than 80 per cent of those who smoke become addicted before they are 20. This is the key age group on which we must concentrate-the teenage years. The pedlars of tobacco know that so they deliberately target their promotional and advertising strategies to hook the young because they are after victims for life.

Recent activities in the United States Congress have been aimed at thwarting such behaviour. In fact, the House of Representatives this year held hearings to consider a ban on all promotions of tobacco products. In the United States Senate, Senator Bill Bradley has introduced a measure to eliminate the tax deduction for tobacco promotion as a business expense and to require tougher health warnings and higher excise on tobacco products. I believe that this is something that we should follow in Australia; it is a pity that we could not have been in the lead. Last year the National Advisory Council on Drug Abuse voted nine to one to recommend a total ban on cigarette advertising and promotion in the United States. In part this was based on government estimates that 350,000 Americans died as a result of their smoking habit. It emerged from the Council that cigarettes are the most widely advertised product in America with more than $US1,500m being spent for this purpose. This is an enormous waste of resources. In Australia we spend around $80m and we could save $40m from the public purse as a result of this amendment. Indeed, the Opposition should support this because it would thus be supporting both better health for Australia and more revenue. I believe that the Government, too, should support this. If these are hard times why should the tobacco industry get away scot-free?

The situation in Australia is a bit harder to unravel because of the obsessive secrecy which pervades the tobacco pushing operations. The best figures I have relate to 1983 and apparently have the imprimatur of the Australian Chamber of Commerce. The figures for 1983 were: $54m on print, cinema and billboards; $15m on merchandising material; and $13m on sports and cultural sponsorship. That totals up to the $82m, roughly what I mentioned earlier. With the explosion in advertising rates and the further insinuation of tobacco interests into sporting and cultural activities, the figure could be well over $100m this year. That means that the Government would be forgoing $50m worth of revenue, and doing this at the expense of the health of the Australian community. The Tobacco Institute of Australian contents itself with a figure of around $80m, so we are definitely in the same ball park. That is the type of expenditure that the Government is throwing away. We could retain most of the social welfare measures that the Australian Democrats have been trying to maintain if we dealt properly with the tobacco industry. We could keep the Special Broadcasting Service independent of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation; we could keep the Institute of Multicultural Affairs. All of these involve very small amounts compared with the $40m minimum and probably $50m to $60m that one would hope to gain from this single amendment. The Prices Surveillance Authority made these comments in its 1985 report after it received applications for price rises:

Advertising is a major form of non-price competition in the Australian cigarette market. For all companies, advertising constitutes a major cost item and hence is reflected in prices. It is employed to create and foster a brand image, and to tailor brands for a specific group of consumers, thus splitting the market into taste, style, packaging and price segments.

We all know that the principal aim of such advertising is to hook young smokers for life. Honourable senators will recall that the Movement Opposing the Promotion of Unhealthy Products-MOPUP-fought for over 18 months to persuade the Advertising Standards Council that the market leader in cigarette advertising was abusing the voluntary code of ethics by pitching its message, successfully, at children. A lot of billboard advertising since them has clearly been aimed at the young female market, which is seen as a promising target group. Indeed, smoking has increased in this group. Such billboards tend to be retouched more quickly than others by the BUGA-UP network, a group of people called Billboard Utilising Graffitists Against Unhealthy Promotions. I believe that they are adding to the advertising costs of tobacco companies to some extent and, if this amendment were passed, they would be adding to government revenue as a result of the non-deductibility of cigarette advertising. The only way the tobacco interests can survive is to produce addicts out of beginners. This is one of the major problems that we are facing in Australia today.

We have a real problem in the advertising of tobacco. Tobacco is known to cause cancer, emphysema and a number of diseases, not only diseases which kill but diseases which are completely debilitating. The net saving to the Australian economy through the amendment would be much greater than what can be obtained by this revenue measure alone. The revenue measure on its own will net $40m, but the long term saving in medical costs, which are highly subsidised by the state, will be enormous. I believe that it is extremely important that we handle the matter in this way.

I would like particularly to mention a few points about the misrepresentations which are involved in some of these advertisements. I believe that it is relevant to do so because the Australian taxpayer is subsidising these advertisements. We recently had referred to the Trade Practices Commission an outrageous example where research carried out by the Institute of Cancer Research in the United Kingdom was falsely reinterpreted by the Tobacco Institute of Australia. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard the text of a letter sent to a newspaper by the Cancer Research Institute.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Questionable smoking data

SIR, You recently published advertisements inserted by the Tobacco Institute of Australia which contain misleading propaganda about the health effects of passive smoking. The Tobacco Institute, without authorisation, has used the name of the Institute of Cancer Research to support its proposition that passive smoking carries no significant increase in the risk of lung cancer, bronchitis or heart disease for non-smokers.

We would like your readers to be aware that these conclusions have not been drawn by the institute. The study, carelessly referred to in the advertisements, was funded by the UK Tobacco Advisory Council, which represents the tobacco industry, and was undertaken by three researchers two of whom worked at the Institute of Cancer Research.

The study which the Tobacco Institute claims to support its views in fact indicated an 11-per cent increase in risk of lung cancer in the non-smoking spouses of smokers. However, if the analysis of their data had been restricted to lung cancer patients whose spouses were also interviewed and therefore likely to provide more accurate information, the estimated risk increases to 33 per cent.
Unfortunately the results of the study are not statistically significant because the survey included too few people.
In our view, the risk to non-smokers of developing lung cancer as a result of living or working with smokers may be of the order of one in 1,000.
ROBYN WEISS,
JULIAN PETO,
Institute of Cancer Research,
London, UK.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The Trade Practices Commission seems to be having some difficulty in concluding its investigations of this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year there were some very interesting court battles after the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal clamped down on the practice of turning sporting events into major advertising features for cigarette companies. Cameras would linger for unusually lengthy periods just where the promotional material for cigarettes happened to be attached to the pickets or fences around the ground. The backroom machinations were exposed when the Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia called for copies of contracts between the New South Wales Rugby Football League and the cigarette interests. It is quite clear that there was a commercial ruthlessness about the terms of those contracts. For instance, it was specified that hostesses could provide samples to the public at all competition matches and at all social and other functions organised and controlled by the League. The back cover of the official weekly publication was for cigarette advertising and the brand logo had to appear on the front cover. The brand flags were to be flown at all grounds where competition matches were played. The sponsorship was to be acknowledged on the front cover of the annual report and in the editorial piece. The brand's advertising theme was to be played at all fixtures. There were further requirements for the brand name to be mentioned in all advertising material, Press releases and interviews relating to the Sydney rugby league competition. The brand logo had to be on the playing surface for the finals and prominent advertising space was to be made available around the perimeter of the playing fields. On and on this went.

The truly Faustian nature of the agreement was highlighted in a judgment which upheld the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's actions. I would like to quote page 692 of volume 58 of the Australian Law Reports, which states:

Clause 15 shows that the sponsorship arrangement was intended as an advertising opportunity rather than an act of sporting philanthropy. That clause makes the agreement subject to termination, with a pro rata abatement of the sponsorship fee, in the event of any requirement by a government or by a local `public authority' to remove and cease exhibition of any advertising and or to cease conducting the promotional activities contemplated by this agreement.

I think this is absolutely disgusting. I believe that the taxpayer should not be forced to support this type of unreasonable and dishonest activity. I call upon the Opposition and the Government to put their money where their mouths are and to do the honest and decent thing and vote for this amendment which gives both money to the exchequer and does something towards stamping out a filthy habit in our community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Opposition will not be supporting the amendment. Whatever one's views about the use of tobacco-I will certainly not engage in a long debate about that matter-the question really at issue here is whether this kind of device, in seeking to attach an amendment to a piece of legislation which has nothing to do with this matter, is proper. We in the Opposition have decided that, for those reasons, we will not be supporting this amendment.

—I rise briefly to support my colleague Senator Vigor on this amendment. It was very disappointing to hear from Senator Messner that the Opposition is not prepared to support the Australian Democrats on this vital amendment which would have the effect of addressing some of the false advertising being targeted at the young in our community today. My office in Box Hill happens to be above a very busy railway station through which many young people pass on their way to various tertiary and secondary institutions. I am continually amazed that, almost to a person, these young students are smoking as they go to and from the station. It is the in thing for young people to do today. No doubt they have been influenced by very subtle and insidious advertising campaigns by the tobacco industry. I wonder why the Government will not support this amendment. I wonder why the Opposition will not support this amendment. Are they concerned that vested interests may withdraw funds from their parties? Are they concerned that vested interests may have some influence over our media that could adversely affect their ability to get political comment in the media? I know that we have been threatened with that by various representatives of the tobacco industry. The Democrats have been told that if they proceed with these sorts of amendments which attack the industry they will not get one inch of space in the media again.
—You should report them.

—They do not do it in a way that enables us to report them; they do it through third parties. But their intentions are very clear. I ask: Why will not the Government support this amendment? Why will not the Opposition support this amendment? Senator Messner fools nobody by saying that this is not the appropriate place for such an amendment to be moved. We are talking about tax. Obviously, the tax allowance that the Government grants to the advertising of the tobacco industry is relevant. It is the right place to discuss this issue.
—We had no notice of it and we had no chance of discussing it.

—The Opposition's comments are wearing a little thin. We are continually told that, in due course, the Opposition will come down with a policy decision and then presumably debates in this chamber will mean something. Presumably after the Opposition goes to the mountains it will come down with all the wisdom in the world, it will know what it is going to do, it will know what its policies are and then we can have a debate and find out where it stands. At present the Opposition has no policy on any issue as far as we can see and it is doing nothing other than supporting the Government. The Government has introduced initiatives that are obviously contradictory and it is not good enough for Opposition senators to say that they are supporting Budget measures. That is a straight cop-out. There are pieces of legislation which could be amended.
—You promised that you would never go against money Bills and look what you are doing.

—I am glad that Senator Walters raised that matter because what the Democrats clearly undertook to do and will do is not to block Appropriation Bill (No. 1). We will not cut off money for the ordinary annual services of the Government as the Liberal Party of Australia did in 1975. It stopped the money to pay the bureaucracy. We have said that we will never do that. We will never precipitate a double dissolution. We have said that we will not block Supply. I hope that that means to the honourable senator Appropriation Bill (No. 1), which finances the ordinary annual services of the Government. Opposition senators are attempting to confuse the public by saying: `We cannot block a Budget Bill'. The vast majority of Bills that come before this place have something to do with money. To say that some of these Bills cannot be amended is just not true and Opposition senators are misleading the public in maintaining that point of view. The fact is that there has been some unholy alliance between the Government and the Opposition and the Opposition is saying: `We will support your legislation now and when you are in opposition presumably you will support us'. I do not know whether that is the deal, but obviously some deal has been worked out between the Labor Party and the Liberal Party, as well it might. Any difference between what the Liberal Party is advocating in relation to economic strategy and policy and what the Government is advocating certainly escapes me. Both policies are as far Right as they can possibly be.
—You are far Left.

—We represent people; we represent the middle ground; we represent Australians owning Australia; and we represent government managing the economy. The Government and the Liberal Party want to sit back and let the market run this country.
—Order! Senator Siddons, you are getting rather far away from Senator Vigor's amendment.

—I thank you, Mr Chairman. I was making the point that it is a great pity that the Opposition has not been able to formulate its policy and operate constructively in the Senate which should be a House of review and which should take on the job of improving the legislation that the Government brings down. If that had been done, the impact on the Australian people of the Government's ill-advised economic strategy could have been lessened, and it would have been greatly to the benefit of all Australians. As it is now, there is little doubt in our minds that the Government's strategy will lead to a recession or a depression of monumental proportions. This could have been lessened to a very great degree if we had been able to get through this Parliament amendments which would have forced the Government to reconsider at least some of its policy initiatives. That has not been possible because the Liberals have not been able to make up their minds. This matter before us-the reduction of a tax rebate on the advertising of tobacco-would, as my Senate colleague pointed out, gain the Government revenue and, at the same time, redress a great evil in our society and a great expense in medical costs. That is not to be, unfortunately. We can do no more than stand our ground and advocate what we see as being right. We will continue to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Considering that the Opposition is not supporting us-it was given some notice of this-I would like to point out that some people in the Opposition--
