TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Messner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Siddons has drawn my attention to a very good point about repetition. He will get plenty of it during this debate. There will be a very long debate on the Appropriation Bills because the Opposition has many points to make in respect of the Government's handling of the economy. It has now been drawn to our attention, by virtue of the release of the consumer price index figures today, that the latest quarterly increase in the consumer price index is 2.6 per cent. That is the highest quarterly increase in the consumer price index since--
—Since John Howard was Treasurer.

—That is exactly right-since John Howard was the Treasurer; since this Australian Labor Party came to power. Quite in contrast to the arguments that have been put by the Government that the economy is undergoing some kind of recovery due to the effect of its so-called J-curve and because the Budget is supposed to be sound, logical and right for the time, we now have the highest level of inflation ever in this country as a result of the Government's policies. Having been advised this morning that the Government has the highest rate of inflation since it came to office in March 1983, that gives us very real concern as to the direction of this Government's policies. Clearly they are going awry. Clearly we are in for higher bouts of inflation, higher taxes and more and more debt. It is the question of debt on which I would like to focus later in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to realise that the Budget, which was supposed to be designed to show a very substantial decrease in the Government's deficit on its own spending and thereby to cause a fall in interest rates, has now been followed by the inflationary result for the first quarter to the end of September which shows that interest rates will again rise. Clearly, while inflation remains at those very high levels, suggesting an overall inflation rate for the year of in excess of 10 per cent, we can expect only more and more increases in interest rates. The consequences of that are obvious. We will have fewer and fewer housing starts and young people trying to buy homes will find it more and more difficult to do so. People who want to buy cars on hire purchase will find it more and more difficult to do so.

The motor vehicle industry is predicting already that the industry will be down by over 150,000 units this year, and that is expected to continue for at least the next two years. That figure is a direct result of this Government's action. It is due not only to very high interest rates but also to the introduction of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and other taxation measures such as the new sales tax rates on luxury motor cars. All of those things have had their effect upon the car market, which sooner or later must be reflected in job losses in that industry. That is the unfortunate consequence of the Government's policies in respect of the total economy. Clearly it is starting to show up as being totally out of the Government's control.

I am concerned that the Government still fails to grasp the fundamental problem with the Australian economy; that is, simply, a lack of competitiveness with the rest of the world. Our inability to sell our goods on the world markets and the inability of our domestic markets to compete with imported goods coming from cheaper cost countries overseas are becoming endemic. We have a situation where every month we are having to find $1.5 billion in order to meet the shortfall between our exports and imports. That can be found only from increased borrowings from overseas. When this Government came to power the total overseas debt to the rest of the world was about $35,000m. Today it is nearly $100,000m and rising.

I would like to dwell on that point for a moment, because I am reminded of a speech given recently by Sir Arvi Parbo, the Chairman of Western Mining Corporation Ltd. Sir Arvi is well known in the business community for his views on the affairs of the nation generally and the problems of the country. Sir Arvi pointed out during his speech that the monthly current account deficit on our balance of payments will continue to run at approximately $15,000m a year. When that is boiled down, it amounts to an increasing debt of approximately $30,000 for every minute that business is conducted in this country. The situation as envisaged by Sir Arvi Parbo is that we are probably looking now, because of the inexorable rise of this debt each year, to a figure of $150,000m worth of overseas debt by the beginning of the 1990s.

It is something of a shock to all of us in the Senate when we realise that this huge rise from $35 billion to $100 billion since this Government came to power is only the start. In fact, we are now looking at a level of $150 billion within the next few years. What is that Government doing about it? Of course, the problem is compounded with an increasing deficit on our balance of payments every month of $1,500m that has to be found by borrowing overseas. It seems that the only way we can encourage people to bring in money from overseas is to keep our interest rates so high that money is brought in at the expense of other nations. The simple fact is that interest rates in this country are about twice as high as those of the countries with which we trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous.
—As Senator Peter Baume points out, it is outrageous. It has a detrimental effect upon the whole of our economy and as a result costs Australians jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, the solution to Australia's economic problems lies in increasing the incentive for investment, encouraging more and more companies and new enterprises to invest in Australia, encouraging Australians to work in them and creating more and more jobs. But who will take the risk of putting their money into a risky investment, a new industry, with all of the risks associated with dealing with the trade union movement and with the taxes imposed by this Government, such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, when they can put their money into the short term money market and get 19 per cent interest on it? Who will put their money into risky ventures when they can get such interest rate returns? Clearly that is the problem that this country faces. The incentive to take the risk, to establish a new industry and create new jobs for Australians, just does not exist. This is a direct result of this Government's policies of keeping interest rates at the highest level ever in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—They are the highest ever in real terms. We should listen well to the words of Sir Arvi Parbo; he is not the only person who has spoken on this matter. In the last few days we have seen statements on the same point. The statement from the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the Government's own independent economic advisers, which was released last week showed that the level of debt in this country will continue well into the 1990s. It is hoped by these advisers that we will be able to stabilise that debt figure at about 40 per cent of gross domestic product in the 1990s. If that is so, we are talking about a level at least as high as the present level of $100,000m applying right through the 1990s. So it is quite feasible that Sir Arvi Parbo's figuring of $150,000m is quite within the realms of possibility. It is a staggering figure and one that must concern all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to realise that 80 per cent of Australia's export income comes from two sources-mining and agriculture. Only 20 per cent of our exports come from other sectors such as manufacturing or services. That is a very small proportion. Yet, while recognising that problem, it is true that in the past a far higher proportion of our export income came from manufacturing. At one stage we were a significant exporter of motor vehicles to the Pacific, to South Africa and to many nations all over the world. But today we export only components to other parts of the world. Of course, I am thinking of the very big effort made in recent years by General Motors-Holden's Ltd in selling four-cylinder motor engines overseas.

Nevertheless, while in the past we have been a manufacturer and an exporter of manufactured products, we are simply not meeting our obligations into the future. What is the potential for us to do that in the future? That remains an enormous challenge. We certainly have the markets around this area of the world. We could attempt to get involved in selling more and more manufactured exports to countries such as India and developing giants such as China. We have the opportunities to do that in those countries, which have potential for enormous markets. But, in order to do that, we need new investment in this country. We need investment in new plant; we need new ideas and know-how so that people will be prepared to work hard to develop those markets, to produce more and more goods manufactured in this country, which can be sold in that part of the world, and thus provide jobs for Australians. While disincentives, such as the very high interest rates that I have already mentioned, plus of course the taxes introduced by this Government in recent times, such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax remain, we will not have the kind of activity so desperately needed in this country to generate jobs for Australians. The survey released by the Bureau of Industry Economics only yesterday shows that our pessimism about manufactured exports is substantiated. Indeed, there is not very much good news in that report about the future development of exports of manufactured goods to world markets. In fact, after reading the report, one becomes quite depressed about the outlook. One hopes that the situation will change.

To sum up, the situation is that we face an enormous challenge to try to develop new industries that can employ Australians in the manufacturing sector. Exports must be the key to the development of those industries. How to do that remains the challenge to this Government. We do not have the leadership that is needed from this Government. Clearly, we do not have the policies that ought to be developed. In fact, all of the economic evidence at the moment points in the opposite direction. We have an inflation rate which now runs at 20 times higher than that in Japan, with whom we do business. The average inflation rate of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries in Europe and of America and Japan is only one-fifth of the inflation rate in this country. This Government cannot say that the inflation rate is improving because clearly it is getting worse. The inflation rate for this last quarter is at its highest level since this Government came to power.

I will make a few other points about debt and investment. Clearly, there are many people with money to lend and to invest in this country but they simply are not doing so. The reason is that they get far better returns if they put their money off-shore, in other countries, or even invest on the New York, Tokyo or London stock exchanges, than they could get by investing in new enterprises in this country. Even some of our largest financial institutions such as the life insurance companies and the superannuation funds-even the Government's own superannuation fund-are putting their current available moneys off-shore at an unprecedented rate.

The average figure generally quoted is that 40 per cent of current investable funds from such large financial institutions is finding its way into other financial markets overseas. That money should be used for the development of Australian industry; but that is not happening. The reason it is not happening is that there is simply not the return or the incentive available in Australian investment to encourage them to do so. Those institutions have an obligation to their policy holders and to their members to invest in the best available investments, overseas or wherever, in order to ensure that people who need those funds in retirement will get the best possible return on their money. The institutions have a fiduciary obligation to do that and they cannot be coerced or forced in some other way to put their money into non-profitable investments in this country. So those institutions are doing the right thing by their investors. The problem is that right at the centre of this matter is the Government's economic policy. We must turn that around in order to encourage such organisations to put their money into Australian investments and create jobs for Australians.

Just recently statements have emanated from the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It is seeking to establish some forced way of grabbing money from superannuation funds and ensuring that it is used for particular investment in Australian industries. I have never heard anything more short-sighted than that kind of idea. For one thing, it is talking about grabbing 25 per cent of the investment incomes of superannuation funds and then putting it under its own control so that it can be put into investment in Australian industries as it judges best. If 25 per cent of the investment funds of superannuation bodies were to be taken out in that manner, it would mean that the final return that would become available to people when they eventually retired would be significantly reduced. This is the money that builds up over the long period of a person's employment in order to provide a substantial sum of money on which to rely in retirement. Such a measure could mean that those people end up coming back to the social security system rather than being able to cash in their superannuation and have sufficient funds to live upon in their retirement. That is the kind of nonsense consequence that could result from the ACTU's proposal. It could put in jeopardy the retirement income of many thousands of Australians. The ACTU says: `The Government will pick up the tab because everybody will be able to get money out of the social security system if it is needed'. That is the sort of nonsense that is being perpetrated by the ACTU in that particular proposal.

It is an inward looking kind of policy. But the motive is really far more sinister than even that which I have just outlined. The ACTU, of course, is about making sure that the money which would have been accumulated in superannuation funds is in fact put into the hands of unionists so that it can be controlled for their particular purposes and objectives. That is what it is all about. It is about control over the huge amount of money that is available in superannuation funds. It is not about the proper management of those funds; it is not about getting the best possible return for money contributed; it is about controlling those funds so that that money can be distributed in what ever way the union determines. This has been a point of issue in the Senate now for about two years, ever since the trade union movement started to take an interest in superannuation funds. The Opposition has continually pointed out that the concerns of the unions in this area are not about getting the best possible return for the members, the retired people of Australia; they are about grabbing control of literally hundreds of thousands of dollars, hundreds of millions of dollars and, in some cases thousands of millions of dollars in order to direct that money according to the unions' wishes. This proposal is about the gradual control of investment in this country. The latest submission and ideas that have come to the Government from the ACTU are obviously exactly in that mould. They are so inward looking and so small minded that I think they would throw into question, and some jeopardy, the whole investment potential of this country if indeed such ideas were to be followed through

I turn to some of the other issues with regard to debt that are becoming more and more evident these days. We have seen for some time overseas evidence of the growing debt problems between some Third World countries and some banks in the United States of America and other parts of the world. In fact, many American banks have been put under threat as a result of the debt repayment problems of some of the Third World countries, particularly some of those in South America. I am not suggesting that anything like that kind of problem is developing in Australia, but it is clearly of concern to pick up the report of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation this year-which came out only last week-and, looking back, compare, over a period of five years, the total amount of loans by the banks with the actual deposits in the banks' hands. One sees that the ratio of loans to deposits has risen very substantially over that time. I would just like to cite some percentages because, looking back to 1982, we can see that loans as a percentage of deposits amounted to only about 70 per cent. That proportion has risen, almost inexorably, to a figure for 1986 of 97.9 per cent. I was interested enough to look at this a little further. Unfortunately, I do not have comparative information, but it seems that the ratio of advances to deposits for all banks in Australia is indeed rising very substantially. I note that the National Australia Bank Ltd is up to about 100 per cent; the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd is 95.2 per cent; Westpac Banking Corporation is 87.3 per cent; and the Commonwealth Banking Corporation is just under 97 per cent.

I am not suggesting that there is anything to be concerned about in this but, indeed, a pattern of a growing level of debt is arising in our banking system. Clearly this is contributing to some concern in the community generally about the amount of borrowings that this country is undertaking overseas. Looking at an article by Christopher Jay which appeared in this morning's Australian Financial Review under the headline `Debt build-up putting many firms at risk'-quoting an economist-one has to be concerned about our long term direction in light of the level of debt as a proportion of the total capital used by companies in Australia. It is interesting to note that, in the period of the last 20 years, the ratio of debt to equity, or shareholders' funds, in Australian companies taken as a whole has gone up from 70 per cent to over 120 per cent. So in fact we are seeing an enormous rise in the debt level of companies and, correspondingly, by all accounting tests and objective advice, a relative fall in the ability of companies to meet those debt repayments from their own equity arrangements. This means that there is a growing reliance on more and more debt in order to repay debt and this, consequently, raises concern about the long term viability of Australian companies. I think this aspect of our corporate and banking areas is certainly very much a feature of this Government's administration. We have seen, as I mentioned earlier, that Australian debt overseas has risen from $35,000m when this Government came to power to over $100,000m today.

Returning to the point that Sir Arvi Parbo made, to which I referred a little earlier, that debt has to be repaid some time. The money has to be found from the export income of Australians as they sell goods overseas. Yet we find a falling amount of money coming to us from that source. Indeed, at this stage there is a shortfall on our exports compared with our imports to the tune of $1,500m per month. As I said earlier, that works out to $30,000 per minute for the rate at which we are accumulating debt overseas. We have to face up to these problems, and certainly the way in which the Government is attacking them does not give us confidence that it is meeting them by attacking them at the root. In fact, all the measures that have been taken by the Government in dealing with the trade union movement, such as the so-called accord, have only contributed quite obviously to higher and higher rates of inflation in this country.

This is not to speak of taxation, to which I shall now turn. Clearly taxation is having an impact in driving up the cost of living and of lowering living standards of all Australians. The infamous fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, the disallowance of entertainment expenses legitimately incurred for business purposes and many other forms of taxes that have been introduced even in this Budget, have led this Government to be the highest taxing government in the history of Australia. Now 25.5 per cent of our gross production goes to taxes for the Federal Government. This flies in the face of the solemn promise given by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) before the 1984 election when he clearly stated in his policy speech that there would be no increases in taxes over and above the taxation applied in the previous year. In his first year in office he succeeded in breaking that promise, along with a heap of others, as we have all come to know too well so often occurs with that particular gentleman.

There were statements before the 1983 election that there would be no lump sum superannuation tax, and of course we got it. We also heard that there would be no assets test on pensions, and of course we got it. We also heard that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy-this was said before the 1984 election just two years ago-and of course we got that in this latest Budget as well. Clearly this is a Government of broken promises which has not at heart the real interests of Australia. Problems are building up on the horizon and we doubt whether the Government has a grip on them. Certainly the Budget represented by this legislation has not come to terms with the fundamental problems of the Australian economy. The Government's attempt in the Budget of August 1986 to pull the wool over the eyes of the Australian population has not convinced the financial markets, has not solved our fundamental problems, and has not convinced the trade union movement because it is in dispute with the Government over the kind of wage system that should apply for the next few years. This Government is in terrible straits.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be selling off their assets.

—That could well be the next line in this disaster, because clearly while borrowing continues to build up at more and more expense to the Budget, the fact is that we are now paying 10c on every dollar of taxation just to pay our interest bill overseas. That has an enormous impact on our Budget and lowers our capacity to be able to pay more for social security or defence or for other normal government purposes.
—Some of that is interest on State government debt.

—No; that is the charge on our Budget-10 per cent of our Budget goes to meet Commonwealth debt servicing. The impact of that is that $7,000m a year comes out of the Budget for that purpose. That is more than our vote for health, more than we spend on defence, and more than we spend on education. It is becoming such a huge factor in Australia's total financial affairs that it is of concern to us all. I conclude by drawing attention to the fallaciousness of this Budget. It has not fooled anybody. While this Government remains in power and fails to address the real issues that are concerning all Australians, it will remain as unpopular as apparently it is now in the gallup polls. It is time that the Government woke up. We need a change; we need a mini-Budget to address the problems associated with the latest inflation figures. It is time that the Government started taking determined action rather than waiting for the rest of the world to sell us down the gurgler.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating jointly the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2). Collectively these Bills comprise the Commonwealth Budget for 1986-87. Appropriation Bill (No. 1) funds from the Consolidated Revenue Fund the ordinary annual services of government. The new amount of money appropriated over and above that in the Supply Bills is $11.3 billion. Appropriation Bill (No. 2) seeks new authorities for some $2.6 billion and essentially the funds in that Bill finance the capital side of the Budget, such as public works, buildings and the new policy initiatives of the Commonwealth Government. Significantly the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) also funds grants to State governments under section 96 of the Australian Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I go on to my substantive remarks, I feel it is important to answer some of the nonsensical claims made by Senator Messner on the economy and on financial matters. I wish first to take up the question of taxation. The Liberals parrot in every speech in this place about the Australian Labor Party being a high tax party. The announcement of substantial and wide-ranging tax cuts in the Press today is made at the very time when Senator Messner is claiming that we are a high tax party. I also take up his claim that the share of taxation from gross domestic product is high under the Labor Party. The fact is that in the period of the Liberal Government in the 1970s and early 1980s, the share of GDP going to taxation rose. In fact, at the time Mr Howard was forced from the Treasury in 1983 by the will of the Australian people, the share of Australia's gross domestic product going in taxation was 1.7 percentage points above the position at the beginning of his tenure as Treasurer. That is one of the very important facts that must be borne in mind-that throughout the life of the Fraser-Howard Government the taxation share of GDP rose from a smaller figure at the beginning of that period to a substantially higher figure at the end, an upward trend in taxation.

Senator Messner also claimed that 10c in every dollar of taxation went in public debt interest. I would have thought that Senator Messner, a former Federal Minister and a man who has been in this place for many years, would know that through the Commonwealth Budget substantial payments of interest are made in respect of debt incurred by State governments. That includes the conservative governments that exist temporarily in Queensland and Tasmania. Senator Messner should have known better than make such an outrageous claim that the interest bill going through the Commonwealth Budget was entirely interest on Commonwealth Government debt. It is not and that argument is fallacious.

At the 1983 National Economic Summit Conference the Hawke Government pledged to fight the country's economic problems, to create new jobs and to reduce inflation. Within the first three years of office of this Government, 500,000 extra jobs were created and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made that promise at the 1983 election. Mr Howard, Leader of the Opposition, and the Liberals scoffed at the idea that so many jobs could be created within three years. Of course, Mr Howard had no right to feel optimistic, because presumably he was basing his comments on his own record as Treasurer. The fact is that in the last 12 months that Mr Howard was Treasurer 186,000 Australians were thrown out of work and were on the industrial scrapheap as a result of his policies. The Hawke Government created 500,000 extra jobs by February of this year-within the three years as promised. Since the National Economic Summit in April 1983 more than 650,000 extra jobs have been created in Australia. That figure is well ahead of the pledged figure. Despite all the claims, carping and knocking by the Liberals, it is interesting to note that the great majority of those jobs were in the private sector. The Liberals repeatedly claim that all the jobs being created in Australia are band-aid, make work jobs or community employment program jobs. That is far from the truth; the great majority of the new employment positions which have been created are in the private sector. Those are some of the facts.

This morning Senator Messner claimed that the consumer price index of 8.9 per cent was `a disaster'. He said that it was the highest figure recorded in Australia for some time. Of course it is. But what Senator Messner did not say was that the last time it was higher, the last time that prices in Australia rose by more than 8.9 per cent, the last time that inflation, as measured by the consumer price index, was more than 8.9 per cent, was when the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, himself was Treasurer. That is a fact and it cannot be erased from history. When Mr Howard was Treasurer inflation was not 8.9 per cent, as it is today. Neither was it 9.9 per cent nor 10.9 per cent. In fact, it was 11.5 per cent. That was the record of Mr Howard as Treasurer and it was the highest figure since the Korean War boom.

Senator Messner also said that the 2.6 per cent rise in the consumer price index published today was the highest for some time. It was the highest for some time-in fact, the last time that CPI in Australia rose by more 2.6 per cent was in the December 1982 quarter. We all know who was the Treasurer in that period. It was Mr Howard. In the December 1982 quarter inflation was not on a par with today with a rise of 2.6 per cent; it was in fact 3 per cent. The Liberals have the gall to criticise this Government over the current inflation rate, but their entire political strategy is based on the hope that the electorate has a short memory. That is what it boils down to. Yesterday in this place the Opposition moved a motion accusing this Government of breaking its promises; today it is criticising an 8.9 per cent inflation rate when its own inflation rate was 11 1/2 per cent. The Opposition left the Labor Government with double digit inflation. The entire political strategy of the Liberal Party is to assume and hope that the electorate has a short memory. That is the way it has always been in Australia; the Liberal Party works on that premise. It hopes that the electorate will not remember that the Liberals in government had double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. That was the record of Mr Howard in his years as Treasurer.

After three years of strong growth this Government has made a readjustment to its economic policy. The reason for that has been pointed out in this place before; it is the classic balance of payments constraint faced by the Australian economy. This is not entirely new; it has been documented since the 1920s and 1930s. It was written about again in the 1950s. Now in the 1980s once again the balance of payments has become a blot on the Australian economy and it is holding down rates of growth in the domestic economy. There has been a massive decline in the terms of trade. That essentially measures an index of export prices divided by import prices. It measures the relative movements in average prices for exports compared with imports. In the last financial year, 1985-86, the terms of trade declined by more than one-tenth. There was a one-tenth reduction in the average prices received for our exports compared with our imports in one financial year. That compares with the long term decline in terms of trade of about one per cent per annum; so there is a tenfold effect there which in one stroke wiped something like $4,000m to $5,000m off Australia's national income. The lower prices for our principal exports endorse the point that Australia's national income will fall. The decline in terms of trade is outside the Government's control. Depressed international commodity prices are to blame, and I regret that these will not improve in the near future. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons I rise to speak today is the problems that exist in Queensland and the very clear corruption within the Queensland National Party Government, corruption that one would have to believe is organised and institutionalised. No one seriously suggests that the Queensland Premier's massive $400,000 defamation payout from the Bond Corporation was anything other than a political sling. It was, as a number of people have commented, a conveniently tax-free payout.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, it is with some reluctance that I draw your attention to standing order 418, which states, inter alia, that all imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections-that is, regarding Federal or State members of Parliament-shall be considered highly disorderly, and I simply ask that that standing order be implemented.

—I would draw the Senate's attention to that particular standing order and ask that honourable senators be aware that they are in the hands of the Chair. Senator Jones, I was distracted at the time that you were speaking, but perhaps you will recall that standing order when you resume your speech.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I would remind you that generalised expressions in relation to other forums and politicians therein have not been regarded as infringing that particular standing order in the past and nor should they be at the moment. There is a difficulty when one refers to particular individuals, but not in the generality.
—Yes, Minister. I am simply drawing the honourable senator's attention to the standing order and suggesting that he take note of it when he resumes his speech.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I suppose there could be a debate over whether it is a political sling. It is certainly true to say that $400,000 was paid to the Premier. For what reason I can leave to other members of the Senate to decide for themselves, as I believe the public will eventually decide. A number of people have commented that it is a conveniently tax-free payout under what has been cynically called `the Bond Corporation contributory superannuation scheme'. When I say `Bond' I mean `bon'. There is no difference between the sort of payout received by the Premier or by the National Party Government and the payout received by Norm Gallagher and the action that was taken following any payout to Norm Gallagher or the BLF. Money was received; it was suggested that that money was for industrial protection and as a form of commission and there were charges laid.

SPEECH.PARA: We have now a similar situation in the State of Queensland where members of the National Party Government are receiving money which would appear to be for favours and for successful tenders and for anything that one likes to put his mind to. It is not my opinion; it is the opinion of Sir Roderick Proctor, who is a National Party trustee. Last night in an interview he said that on a number of occasions tenders have been called when it was fairly obvious that it was only a charade, that it had already been decided who was to be granted the contract. Sir Roderick Proctor said: `I am now speaking out, to a degree, because I am trying to be honest.' That is a member of the National Party, a trustee of the National Party, making those comments. They are not comments that the Labor Party is making; they are being made by the National Party itself.

I believe that, with the corruption rife in Queensland today, the thought of a minority National Party government getting back for another three-year term is almost frightening for the people of Queensland and for the people within the Commonwealth of Australia. We can go through some of the happenings in Queensland. Some of the actions point out very clearly that there is corruption within the Government in Queensland. There is the Bond defamation sling that I have just mentioned; Senator Peter Baume drew my attention to the standing order in relation to it. But I still stand by the points that were made and the fact that those points have been reinforced by a National Party trustee, Sir Roderick Proctor.

Let us go through some of the happenings in recent times in Queensland. I have mentioned already the Bond defamation sling. I come to the $145,000 loan handed out to the National Party's Northern Director, Michael Behan, against the advice of bankers and other people who handle the money within government departments. One hundred and forty five thousand dollars was paid out, $85,000 belonging to the Commonwealth; $145,000 which the Premier termed a lousy loan. I suppose one would have to consider that the payment of $145,000 is nothing more than a sling to Michael Behan, another leading light within the National Party.

We have seen Judith Callaghan, the wife of one of the Premier's closest aides, jailed for fraud through betrayal of a position of trust she held within the Government; money was misappropriated by her. Her husband is yet to face trial and I will not mention anything about that at this stage, but it was the same sort of venture. The Auditor-General in Queensland made a statement that there had been a misappropriation of some $200,000. Charges have been laid for a mere $45,000. Two hundred thousand dollars has been misappropriated according to a statement by the Auditor-General in Queensland.

I turn to the case of the brother of a former National Party member for the State seat of Mourilyn being paid $2.4m compensation under the Burdekin River scheme. The person laying down the valuation of that land made a clear valuation of $1.2m. When questioned on it in the Land Court he said that he had brought down a valuation of $1.2m. A former National Party member's brother received $2.4m, twice the amount that the valuer said the land was worth. I do not believe that I need to say anything further. One needs only to lay out the facts and let people make up their own minds. I do believe that when business has a valuer draw up a valuation in accordance with the factors laid down to govern that valuation, and that valuation is $1.2m, it is quite wrong that a National Party member should receive twice the amount that the valuer says the land is worth-$1.2m to $2.4m.

We can talk about the Premier's minder. I am not sure whether Senator Peter Baume will call a point of order on this. Sir Edward Lyons, a former TAB chairman, had been credit betting at the TAB, breaking the law by credit betting. When he was winning he was gathering the funds; when he was losing he was placing it on credit, up to the sum of something like $300,000.

I might say that since the credit betting episode he certainly has resigned, but it was not long after he resigned that we found that he was appointed to the board of East-West Airlines. Then there was an attempt by East-West Airlines and by the Premier to change the standing of a national park, Lindeman Island, and transfer it into a position where East-West Airlines with its new chairman, Sir Edward Lyons, the minder of Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, could develop land and sell off Lindeman Island. It was only through the outcry of the conservationists, the Opposition and the public generally that the Premier of Queensland pulled back and East-West Airlines, because of the pressure put on it by the Federal Minister, decided to pull out of the deal.

We could go further and look at Russell Hinze, the Local Government Minister, the Minister in charge of main roads, the Minister in charge of racing. He has a racing complex at Oxenford; he has an hotel at Oxenford; on the main road to Oxenford they have built a flyover very close to the hotel, which enhances the value of the property very greatly. Continuing with Russell Hinze, he has a gravel quarry which supplied the road gravel. They re-routed under his direction a road to that quarry so that gravel could be taken out for sale, so millions of dollars could be gathered by the Hinze companies. I am not saying that there is anything wrong; I am not saying that they are crooks; I am not saying that they are using public money. I am just putting down the facts and allowing people to make up their own minds in relation to them. I think it is very, very clear that there is corruption within the State Government when people like Sir Roderick Proctor decide to make a public statement-he is a trustee of the National Party-and lay out very clearly some of the very doubtful action that has been taken by the Government itself.

Let us look through the list of some of the things that have happened under this Government. There is the TAB scandal, and I have just talked about that in relation to Sir Edward Lyons; the proposed sale of Lindeman Island to East-West Airlines; the Toowong development and redevelopment; the Jaldale rezoning of the Gold Coast where the Minister again wrote to the Gold Coast authorities and said that they should give another allocation or allow that land to be redeveloped in a particular way to suit someone who again was very high within the National Party; the Film Corporation or the Callaghan affair, with misappropriation of some $200,000 as Mr Doyle, the Auditor-General, said in his report; the Queensland Day Committee misappropriation of $44,000; a former secretary of the Premier being charged with misappropriation of $17,000; the loan to Mr Behan, former National Party Senate candidate, of $145,000 at 4 per cent, $85,000 of the money in that $145,000 belonging to rural reconstruction; the high payout to the Premier by the Bond Corporation for a settlement of $425,000-information that would not come to light until it was continually raised at the hearing of the licence for one of the television stations; and the rerouting of a road by a National Party Minister.

We continue: The statement by the Minister misleading Parliament over his company's involvement; the sale of land at a higher than market value; the Commissioner of Water Resources-a brother of a former member of the National Party Government-receiving twice the valuation of a valuer who was employed by the Water Commission; and the list goes on. It just goes on and on and these are things that have been happening. Do not take my word for the fact that there is corruption. I think we have to take the word of Sir Roderick Proctor. But let us go a little bit further.

Let me, Madam Acting Deputy President, give a couple of quotes-first, the allegation that `corruption seems to have become the norm in Queensland public life under Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen's Government'. That is a quotation of John Moore, President of the Queensland Branch of the Liberal Party, which appeared in the Australian Financial Review on 1 September 1986. He is not a member of the Labor Party, not someone who wishes to see the Government destroyed, but the President of the Liberal Party within Queensland. On 26 August he said that he had never seen such a sustained period of allegations concerning corruption. Another Liberal Party member asked: `What has happened to our basic right of freedom of speech?' That is Senator MacGibbon, a senator of this chamber. Again, Senator MacGibbon, defending his State President, John Moore, said: `The State Government could not suppress comments by serving writs which represent an abuse of political power'. He said very clearly that there was corruption in the Queensland Government, that there was a series of allegations that needed to be answered.

I only hope that those allegations are answered at the next election by the people of Queensland. Madam Acting Deputy President, there is so much corruption in Queensland that one would have to expect that the National Crime Authority would look at some of the action being taken by the Queensland Government and its supporters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In most recent weeks a number of major events have occurred affecting the peace, security and defence of the world at large and, indeed, of Australia. One very happy event was the Navy Week celebrating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy; I wish to refer to it. The other was the very significant meeting of the two super-powers in Iceland.

SPEECH.PARA: First, let me make some comments about the seventy-fifth anniversary of the Royal Australian Navy. There was, in that week, a coming together of the navies of the allies within the Western alliance, the keepers of the free world defence. There was in Sydney port a sail-past, signifying the nature and quality and close co-operation of the Western alliance and a reminder to all Australians of our part in that alliance and that the defence of the free world goes farther than continental defence. It was a reminder to us of the proud history over 75 years of the Royal Australian Navy and of its present state of quality and preparedness. I pay great tribute to those who organised the whole event; I pay tribute to those who, locally in Sydney, such as Rear-Admiral David Martin, had the detailed planning. It was a magnificent spectacle and a spectacle which must have made all Australians proud.

Whilst on that subject, I point out that in May of this year during the debate on the Appropriation Bills I had cause to make, amongst other remarks regarding defence and the Defence Department, some critical remarks about the attitude which I described as a 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. attitude of defence. Quite properly, the Chief of Naval Staff, Vice-Admiral Hudson, wrote to me and indicated to me that if, indeed, that was so of others, it was not so of the Navy. I want to read to the Senate the letter that he wrote to me, which I accept fully and I think every Australian should know of. He said to me in his letter that he would tell me at a point of time what the Navy was doing, not 9 to 5, but 24 hours a day. He wrote:

A summary is produced for me each day to show the disposition of our ships at 1200 Greenwich Mean Time, that is 10 p.m. local time. At that time on 28 of May HMA Ships, Stalwart, Flinders, Brunei and Betano were on passage to the Solomon Islands to assist in relief operations following Cyclone Namu.
Success was off Jervis Bay conducting first-of-class flying trials. Also in the area were Parramatta and Otama, involved in anti-submarine exercises.
Darwin, Sydney, Onslow and Ovens were off Pearl Harbour taking part in the multi-national exercise, RIMPAC '86.
Vampire was in Suva and Perth and Canberra were alongside in Singapore; all these were at immediate notice for sea.
Hobart was at sea in company with Derwent. Otway was also at sea.

Launceston was on patrol off Darwin, Ipswich off Townsville, Geraldton off Broome and Bunbury off Geraldton. Gladstone was in the Fitzroy Island area and Townsville was off Cairns. Geelong was in the Bass Strait on oil rig patrol.
Whyalla was in Sydney about to sail the following morning. Moresby was working in the survey grounds off Port Hedland.
Swan, Cooke, Fremantle, Orion, Warrnambool, Bendigo and Gawler were alongside in ports around the country, undergoing maintenance but at 24 hours notice for sea.

All these ships were manned, armed, stored and fueled for war or any lesser operational eventuality. The RAN is a 24-hour, 365 days a year going concern; we are anything but a 9 to 5 organisation. It probably sounds corny to many Australians (most of whom were safely at home at 10 p.m. on 28 May), but the Navy never sleeps-ashore or afloat, at home and abroad, all day and every day, your Fleet is ready. Some of our sailors may be cold, wet and miserable-and even sea sick and home sick-but they are all ready.
I acknowledge and admire the quality of that letter and may I also acknowledge the final paragraph, in which he writes:

I wish someone would read that into Hansard. I am privileged to command 15,415 men and women (some of whom aren't even of voting age) whose one desire is to serve this country. A little Parliamentary recognition is small recompense.

I think it is a most delightful and very pertinent letter in this, the seventy-fifth year of the Navy service. I am very proud to say that my reference to a 9 to 5 attitude of defence was certainly not a reflection upon the Navy and I am very proud that we have, in this country, people of the quality of Admiral Hudson, and his own colleagues, officers and men of the Navy who really serve us very well indeed.

I want now to move towards the Iceland meeting. Since that meeting a number of comments have been made around the world. In the last 24 hours a most significant series of comments has evaluated the Iceland meeting. The particular comments came from a full meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation allies on their consideration of the President Reagan submissions in Iceland and his actions throughout those negotiations. It is important for this Senate to understand that NATO responded unanimously in saying that it fully supported the approach and the decisions of President Reagan and of the United States of America. That is a statement of unity of the free world. It is a statement which signifies that the free world fully understands why President Reagan would not accept the terms of Mr Gorbachev's offers and why in fact he would not be willing to concede the withdrawal of the strategic defence initiative.

There are two matters of great importance that have to be considered. One must understand that NATO itself would have a very real concern should a part of the Russian offer have emerged and been implemented. That part of that offer was of course the suggestion that there should be the withdrawal of intermediary weapons from Western Europe, whilst some should be retained in Asia. The fact of the matter is that that would mean that the Cruise and Pershing missiles would be withdrawn from Western Europe and a certain number of SS20 missiles withdrawn from Eastern Europe facing the west. It would not in fact, take away all INF missiles in the world. It would not prevent the redeploying of the SS20s towards Western Europe and fundamentally it would expose Western Europe to the terrible dangers that lay before it, prior to the installation of the Cruise and Pershing missiles.

One must understand that in Europe the Warsaw forces are together in one area of land in the east and capable of immediate deployment as a unit. On the other hand, the NATO forces are dispersed throughout the world-America, Canada, the United Kingdom-and cannot be brought together except in a very long period. Also, numerically the NATO forces are weaker than the Warsaw Pact forces and the NATO people have over the years worried very greatly that they could be overrun in conventional war if the Warsaw Pact should move. The great obstacle to such a movement would be if there was a power for retaliation by the West. The West has always taken the view that Russia might take such a move because without Pershing and Cruise missiles the only way that the West could retaliate would be from submarines deployed around the world's seas.

It might be a fair bet by the Russians that they could act and act with impunity without the Americans involved, because it would bring an attack on the American mainland if the Americans should intervene from their submarine missiles. But once the Cruise and Pershing missiles were so deployed, that altered the whole situation and gave a stability to the situation. The important situation is that what is called the MBFR talks-the mutual and beneficial force reduction talks-should go on so that the conventional forces should be reduced in Europe. That is of immense importance. It is a matter that the coalition fully supports. The breakdown of the talks on the basis of the strategic defence initiative produced some controversy throughout the world. Sadly, and quite wrongly, the media and indeed some elements of politics, have tried to present a picture that the action of the SDI was a primary initiative by America; that America was going into high density light beams, laser beams, and particle beams research and development on its own; that it would be ahead of Russia; and that Russia had everything to fear from this because it would create an imbalance in the deterrent. America, of course, having great skills in her technology, would be ahead in scientific development.

The tragedy is that the world has not been told and should be told most forcibly that for the last 17 years-and I repeat, the last 17 years-the Russians have been carrying out not only research into high density light beams, laser beams and particle beams, but also the actual development of an anti-missile system throughout the Russian mainland. Indeed, the Russians have an anti-missile system defence around Moscow. They have at a place called Krasnoyarsk in central Russia a radar array that is generally conceded is a breach of the anti-ballistic missiles treaty and is part of the strategic defence initiative philosophy.

The fact of the matter is that America was not doing something to destabilise. At the very most it was doing something to be in parallel with what Russia was doing. What is more, President Reagan has said emphatically that he is willing to supply to the Russians, step by step, over the whole course of the research of the strategic defence initiative, the information that the Americans have, so that the two of them are in parallel in their development. The Americans have offered a three-stage disarmament. It is very important to understand that what looked like an initial major initiative of Gorbachev in Iceland was in fact part only, an echoing in some substances alone, of what the Americans have been offering now for something like five years in START-the strategic arms reduction talks-that were in fact cut off by the Russians.

The willingness to halve the number of strategic missiles, and on America's part to wipe out all intermediate missiles, was part of the strategic arms reduction talks. The fact of the matter is that the Americans have offered in terms of the strategic defence initiative a simple principle. They have said: `Let us abolish all nuclear weapons throughout the world. Let us take away the aggressive nuclear offence system which creates the deterrent and put in its place a non-nuclear defence system. We are willing to do this in three stages; we are willing to share our knowledge with the Russians; we are willing to cut down our missiles at the same time as we increase our non-nuclear defence system'.

The important thing to understand is that we are being outsmarted by propaganda from the Left. It is important for the people of Australia and the world to understand that what America is doing is striving to wipe out all nuclear missiles from the world, totally, and to put in its place a defence system which is non-nuclear. Nothing could be more admirable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this lunchtime to follow up some matters which came out of the research which I did in looking at an amendment to the taxation Bills which were dealt with earlier this day. I refer particularly to the shocking situation which came to my notice concerning smoking amongst young people. I believe this is a sufficiently important area to bring to the notice of the Senate so that we can actually think about legislative proposals to solve the problem. The Better Health Commission Report, Volume I, `Looking Forward to Better Health', makes a few statements which, I think, are very illuminating in this area. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . smoking is most prevalent among members of the lower socio-economic groups.
That is one point. Point two says:
. . . girls are taking it up in greater numbers than boys.

That is an interesting discrimination which is happening through the process of advertising. Thirdly we are told that lung cancer among women will soon be the leading cause of cancer death in women-the rates have, in fact, risen by 30 per cent between 1980 and 1984. I managed to get some statistics which were supplied by the Australian Association of Cancer Registries and I seek leave to incorporate a table. I have shown it to both sides of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Better Health Commission goes on to comment later that taxation increases discourage children most and children have the lowest per capita cigarette consumption rates. Currently, advertising is still having an effect on young children, despite laws in various States which stop the selling of cigarettes to young children. There is still consumption by young children and many are apparently addicted to cigarettes by the time they reach the age of 18. This is a real indictment of our system. I would bring to the notice of the Senate, but not go any further, an admirable presentation-the sixteenth Leonard Ball oration at the Royal Women's Hospital in Melbourne-which was delivered by Senator Peter Baume, who is here today. I would commend him for his analysis of the problem. I would hope that we can co-operate in trying to get this particular scourge wiped from the face of Australian society. I believe that we should look very closely at how this can be done.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prices Surveillance Authority, in its `Inquiry in relation to the supply of cigarettes', published on 26 November 1985, says that the elasticity of demand for cigarettes is very low. It is higher for light smokers than for heavy smokers and overseas evidence puts teenagers' price elasticity as very high. Teenagers may, in the first instance, switch to cheaper brands but in the long term they will actually stop smoking if they are priced out of it. I believe we should consider massive hikes in cigarette prices as one possible means of stopping this particularly obnoxious habit, which harms not only the person who is smoking, but also those who take in sidestream smoke.

Currently, I wish to bring to the notice of the Senate, we are spending around $400m on hospital bed days each year because of cigarette-caused illness. We can tackle the public health question in probably two different ways simultaneously: First, we can go after the advertising and promotion activities of the dealers who are pushing this particular process. We could ban it, as the Australian Medical Association has proposed. Secondly, we could put tobacco further and further out of the reach of the most vulnerable; that is, the young and the people who are currently being affected by the massive advertising and promotion campaigns which are being run in sporting areas where young people are the main participants.

There is a very interesting section in the report of the Better Health Commission which talks about the prerequisite for getting more data on smoking. I believe that it is extremely important to know what we are up against when we are dealing with a problem of this type. According to the Better Health Commission, we do not have suitable and satisfactory statistics sufficient to be able to make sensible policies in this area. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard from the Better Health Commission's report the section dealing with the type of statistics that it believes we should be collecting if we really are serious about tackling this problem. It has been shown to both sides.
Leave granted.
The section read as follows-
In their plan for `a national strategy on tobacco smoking control', outlined in June 1981, the National Health and Medical Research Council singled out the following areas for data collection:
epidemiology of tobacco-related diseases;
total per capita consumption of tobacco and cigarettes;
tar-weighted cigarette consumption;
past and present smoking habits of the population;
costs to the economy of tobacco smoking and related illness;
real costs of tobacco and cigarettes-related to wages and the Consumer Price Index;
smoking habits of certain target groups-for example, pregnant women;
smoking habits of exemplar groups-for example, doctors and teachers;
measurement of all media usage in relation to tobacco information, education and advertising, direct and indirect.

The gathering of survey data on smoking attitudes and behaviour in adolescents is also vitally important because tobacco smoking is usually begun during the teenage years. Systematic data of this kind are not available in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report points out that, unlike the United Kingdom and the United States, Australia has no systematic population-based statistics. It goes further to remind us of the national strategy on tobacco smoking control outlined in June 1981 by the National Health and Medical Research Council. Among the items we need to collect data on smoking habits are, in fact, the smoking habits of certain target and exemplary groups. The Council has stressed the importance of evaluating the cost to the community of tobacco smoking and related interests. The importance of the information, which is included in the report and which I commend to everybody, is that it does give the basis if we had the information in a hard form of showing exactly what the costs of smoking are to the community. This must spread a lot further than just the straight medical costs.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also deals with the area of subsidising, of absentees from work, and extra cleaning expenses in places where smoking is carried on. I believe that we can learn something from looking at this type of information as it has been gathered in the United States. In the United States, the Congressional Quarterly gives an estimate of $US22 billion as how much the United States health care system needs each year to treat smoking-related diseases. Of course, they have a lot more people than us. The indirect cost of lost productivity due to smoking-related diseases in 1985 was put at around $US43 billion, around twice the amount for treatment. In fact, of the cost per packet, health care alone was between 70 and 80 per cent of the price paid by the victims who smoked a particular brand.

I believe that if we apply the same type of statistics in Australia, we could save from our medical areas-from our absenteeism figures, from all the areas of importance in the community which are affected by smoking-sufficient to be able to make massive tax cuts, of the order of around 10 per cent at least, on income tax. I believe we should be endeavouring to do this type of thing. However, in Australia we just do not have the information available to us. The best that we have is information based on hospital bed-days in Western Australia and that gives, multiplied for the whole of Australia, an estimate of $400m nation-wide; that corresponds to the $US22 billion figure in the United States. If we included the other figures, we would arrive at about three times that amount as the sum that could be saved if we could eradicate this particular problem from the community.

I would like to remind the Senate of recommendation 51 of the Standing Committee on Social Welfare in its 1977 report, `Drug Problems in Australia-an Intoxicated Society?'. Recommendation 51 was as follows:
That excise policy be one tool used to reduce the consumption of tobacco.

When the Government responded to that report, 2 1/2 years later, it did so in a completely unenthusiastic manner. In fact, its response was that tax rates on tobacco products are matters to be determined in a budgetary context and that the Government would take health considerations into account in setting those rates. I believe that the health considerations should come first. In fact, when we examine the 1985 annual report of the Australian Tobacco Board we find that the excise on cigarettes was increased only twice during the course of the Fraser years in office. There was a rise of just over 27.5 per cent in August 1978, just after an election, and a rise of 20 per cent in August 1982, just before an election. But that was not known at the time.

These long intervals meant that the price of cigarettes did not keep up with inflation and that the price deterrent was not working at all. In fact, the Australian Medical Association made this point strongly to the inquiry of the Industries Assistance Commission into the Australian tobacco industry in 1982.

The following measures, amongst others, were proposed: That any future reference on the tobacco industry include consideration of the cost to the community attributable to tobacco-related diseases. Secondly, that a penal duty be applied universally to all tobacco leaf and manufactured cut tobacco imported into Australia. Thirdly, that the excise tax on cigarettes and on other tobacco products be increased by a minimum of 50 per cent in the 1982-83 Budget and that it be automatically indexed to movements of the computer price index. The Fraser Government, in fact, went for only a 20 per cent increase.

Treasurer Keating has now tied the excise movements to the consumer price index. But there was a further period of increase between 1982 and the time when he did this of the order of 5 per cent. I believe it is shameful that this Government has not at any stage made a major catch-up adjustment similar to that which several States have done recently on their licensing fees. A major increase, I believe, would discourage enough young people from smoking to make that well worthwhile and would be a much better measure than some of those which have been brought in in the Budget. I commend to the Senate a policy of strongly discouraging drug taking. Tobacco is one of the most dangerous drugs that we have got, despite the fact that it is a legal drug.

I would commend to the Senate that we should immediately consider what type of measures can be put into place to make our society much healthier and to save an enormous amount of suffering and ill health within the community. The way of doing this is to take seriously the problems of smoking within the community, particularly amongst young people who are now the main target of the tobacco moguls.
