TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the usual practice in this place to make criticisms of the judiciary and I hope that the comments that I make are taken in that way, because this afternoon I want to make some constructive comment. It is about a matter which came before the Supreme Court of Queensland not so long ago. In the Courier-Mail on 2 September of this year there was an article which was headed `Unlimited liquor supply at Mission worry: Judge'. The first paragraph of this article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A Supreme court judge yesterday said he could not understand or come to grips with the idea that Aboriginals in areas such as Doomadgee mission in the Gulf of Carpentaria, had unlimited access to liquor.

When I read that I was surprised because quite often people come before the courts, not only in Queensland but elsewhere in Australia, whose offences have been due to over-indulgence in alcohol. It seems to me that this happens not only to Aboriginals but to non-Aboriginals as well. This article in the Courier-Mail seemed to indicate that this particular judge was criticising the fact that this person, as an Aboriginal who lived at Doomadgee mission had an unlimited access to liquor. In other words, he had an access which was similar to that of non-Aboriginals.

I took the trouble to obtain a copy of the actual judgment because articles like that in the newspapers are sometimes misleading. I would like to read the relevant part from the judgment which the article in the Courier-Mail referred to. His Honour Mr Justice Moynihan said, in part, when sentencing this person:

Lorraine, you have pleaded guilty to unlawful killing. It occurred in circumstances which are only too common, for people in your position, that is where there has been an excessive consumption of alcohol, and a dispute arose which you seemed to regard as capable of resolution only by violence.
The next paragraph is perhaps the relevant one to the matter that I am referring to this afternoon. It says:

As I say, in this Court, people in your position are increasingly finding themselves charged with such offences. How it is right that people in your position should have unlimited access to liquor is something which I can't really understand or come to grips with but that is what seems to happen.

That is probably a little different from the construction that was placed upon it in the Courier-Mail article, but the message seems clear, namely, that the judge was saying that this person should not have had the same access to liquor as people who are not Aboriginals. I do not want to go into the argument about whether people should have access to liquor or not. That is a different matter altogether. But it seems to me that in Australia it should not matter whether one is of European descent, comes from some other area of the world, or of Aboriginal descent in having access to alcohol.

I would suggest that the judge's statement is probably bordering on being a racist comment. I would just ask the judge, and those who are connected with the justice system in Queensland and elsewhere, to remember that Aboriginals are Australians and we should not distinguish between them and non-Aboriginal Australians when we are talking about their access to alcohol, access to other commodities or rights or privileges that people have if they are not of Aboriginal descent. The matter is serious enough to raise it here and I hope that in future we will not see any similar occurrence of this type of discrimination entering into judgments in Queensland.
Sitting suspended from 1.35 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the fact that today's consumer price index figure takes the annual inflation rate to 8.9 per cent, more than 5 1/2 times the average of the major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations. Does he believe that the Budget decision to seek a 2 per cent discount at the next national wage case remains adequate in light of this larger than expected quarterly increase? Given the findings of the Bureau of Industry Economics report released yesterday, to which the Minister referred in Question Time yesterday, that costs have offset the advantages of devaluation, does the Minister believe there is now a need for a tighter clamp on wages and deferral of the union superannuation campaign which, if successful, will add significantly to industry costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The CPI increase announced today was quite within the range expected by the Government following the devaluation of the dollar.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Any honourable senators who have been reading the papers or serious journals would not have expected a very different result. That follows the further devaluation of the dollar which occurred particularly in June and July of this year and, as I have said, the increase is within the expected range. Senator Chaney asks whether that makes the annual inflation rate in the order of five times that of the average OECD rate. I am unable to answer that precisely but I take his point that that inflation rate on an annualised basis is considerably higher than the OECD average rate. I simply make the point that a number of factors have led to that average OECD rate, in particular so far as European countries have contributed to that average. Of course, the main factor is the dramatic fall in oil prices. By giving that answer, I am not seeking to suggest that some countries have not had a better inflation performance than Australia anyway, but it is a significant factor to be taken into account when making those comparisons. Senator Chaney then asked me whether in the light of the 2.6 per cent inflation figure for the quarter the Government would reassess the 2 per cent discounting of wages which was referred to in the Budget Papers. I am not quite sure from recollection what the anticipated inflation rate for 1986-87 was in the Budget Papers, but it certainly was not one which we could say with great joy compared favourably with that of other OECD countries.
—It is very serious.

—Yes, and so is the honourable senator. As to whether that leads to the Government changing its position in respect of wages, negotiations are currently taking place with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and a number of business organisations regarding the wage fixation system and an appropriate wage environment for our current economic circumstances. All I can say is that in all those negotiations the Government will be advancing the position that any wage changes have to take account of the overall economic position, and we will be adopting a very stringent position in respect of those matters consistent with the view expressed at the time of the Budget, having regard to the economic outlook then.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked also about superannuation claims. That is also the subject of discussion between business organisations and the ACTU. Until those discussions are complete, I am not in a position to say anything about that matter. I think they are positive and constructive discussions, and that is what the Government is seeking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Leader of the Government for his reply. I note with some concern his acceptance of the 2.6 per cent quarterly inflation rate as being within the range expected. I add that the $1.4 billion trade deficit, on last month's figures, might also have been within the range expected. But I ask the Minister: In light of the current figures the Government is receiving in respect of inflation, the trade deficit and so on, is the Minister saying that the policy settings which were laid down in the August Budget are still satisfactory and do not require alteration?

—I was trying to say that all these matters have to be taken into account. I understand the Opposition's desire to put the trade deficit figure together with the inflation figure in an attempt to talk the dollar down.
—Fair go. Good heavens, I did not mention the dollar.

—It has been mentioned outside this place. I apologise to Senator Chaney if that was remote from his mind when he asked the question. Let me get back to the point. Senator Chaney keeps pursuing me as to whether any further adjustment is considered necessary as a result of this inflation figure. I really cannot add anything to what I said in the earlier part of my answer. The Government has to be concerned about obtaining adjustments in the wages area, particularly, but until we finalise our position on the question of the two-tier wage structure and so on, matters which are the subject of negotiation, I do not think it would be beneficial for me to make any further comment. I was not in any way trying to be sanguine about the high inflation rate. It is the highest inflation rate for any one quarter Australia has had since John Howard was Treasurer, and that is a matter of considerable concern, given the current economic circumstances.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer read the highlights of the address by the Chairman of MIM Holdings Ltd, Sir Bruce Watson, to shareholders at the company's annual general meeting published in the Australian Financial Review this morning and the transcript of an interview with Sir Roderick Proctor, a trustee of the Queensland branch of the National Party, on the Carleton-Walsh Report last night? If so, given Sir Bruce Watson's comments about the implications of Federal taxation policy and Sir Roderick Proctor's comments about Queensland rail freight charges, can the Minister give an indication of the relative implications of Federal taxes and State charges on the cost structure of Mount Isa Mines? Do the results of this comparison confirm Sir Roderick's views expressed last night about the Bjelke-Petersen National Party Government's management of the Queensland economy?

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The early part of the question is probably within the Minister's competence but the latter part, which merely calls for a comment on the affairs of another government, seems to go beyond the province of Question Time and I ask you to rule it out of order.

—Order! The first portion of the question is clearly in order and it is on that basis that I allow the Minister to answer. I know that the Minister has been told over and over again that he shall not debate matters and I know that he has heeded that advice and will continue to do so.

—I appreciate your ruling, Mr President, and I am not canvassing it, but my point was that the latter part of the question was beyond the Minister's responsibilities and I was suggesting that that part of the question, whether debated or not, was not in order.
—We will listen to the Minister's response.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the first two parts of the question and observe in passing that Senator Chaney is again swimming against the tide of the Liberal Party by trying to protect the corrupt National Party Government in Brisbane whereas senior Liberal Party officials in Queensland are passing on the message that if this Government can dig up some dirt on the Queensland Government, they would like to get a piece of it.
—Senator Chaney does that because Senator Boswell is standing over him.
—Order! The point of order taken by Senator Chaney has been determined. I ask the Minister to respond to Senator Black without debate.

—Certainly, Mr President. In response to the first part of the question, I have not read the transcript of Sir Roderick Proctor's comments but I have heard extracts from it. I understand that, since then, Sir Roderick has, to some extent, backed away from what he said. I can only speculate as to why that is so. Perhaps he has heard about what happens to other people who argue with officials of the National Party of Australia. They sometimes get a hard hit on the back of the head.

ANSWER.PARA: More significantly perhaps, Sir Roderick's comments were endorsed on a Macquarie radio program this morning by another Queensland knight, Sir Robert Mathers, who said:
. . . I might say that I agree wholeheartedly with the sentiments Sir Roderick expressed.
He went on:
I think one of the big things is the cronyism.

That is, one of the big things in the election campaign is the cronyism. In response to the second part of the question I have figures on the payments by Mount Isa Mines Ltd to the Queensland Government and to the Commonwealth Government. Sir Roderick also made a statement which was directly relevant to this. He said:

. . . Queensland is an extremely high taxed State. The high taxes on the coal mining industry which are gathered in the guise of rail freights are exceedingly high. It also has many other high State taxes such as the tax on the new Gold Coast Casino which at 20 per cent is, we believe, the highest in the world, certainly the highest in Australia.

That was said by Sir Roderick Proctor. I deal now more specifically with the highlights of Sir Bruce Watson's report to the annual meeting of Mount Isa Mines. In the last financial year Mount Isa Mines paid a total of $7.6m in Federal taxes, which comprised $2m in sales tax, $4.2m in excise duty and $1.4m in company tax. In the same year MIM paid $54.9m in direct State taxes to the Queensland Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's terrible.

—Yes. That included payroll tax of $11.8m, land tax of $300,000, royalties of $42m, stamp duty of $100,000 and mining lease rents of $700,000. So MIM paid direct taxes of $54.9m to the Queensland Government and $7.6m to the Commonwealth Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Then, of course, there is the question of rail freights which Sir Roderick Proctor addressed. MIM's rail freight charge-this is for coal alone-was $83.3m in the last financial year, of which just over $61.2m was a hidden State tax. It was not a charge for a service but a State tax which was hidden. The rail freight charge from the Mount Isa mine-which is distinct from coal of course; it is not a coal mining operation-was $65.2m, of which Mount Isa Mines estimates that some $27.7m was a hidden State tax and not a charge for a service delivered. So, in total, taxes paid to the Queensland Government by Mount Isa Mines, hidden and unhidden, were $145.8m as against $7.6m paid to the Federal Government.

To the extent that taxes are a problem for Mount Isa Mines, it is very clear where the source of that problem is-it is in Queensland and not in Canberra. Bearing that in mind, I expect that it will not be very long before Sir Bruce Watson joins the revolt with the other Queensland knights, Sir Robert Mathers and Sir Roderick Proctor, and calls for the removal of the Bjelke-Petersen Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, concerns Federal matters, which is slightly different from what we have been experiencing over the last three weeks. —I do not know what certain oil companies are demanding on this issue. I will find out and give the honourable senator an answer as soon as possible.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, refers to the dismissal with 30 minutes notice of 300 employees at Besco Batteries in Sydney last Friday. Does this action by a subsidiary of Peko-Wallsend Ltd provide any insights into the type of alternative industrial relations system being advocated by the New or extreme Right in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure what the answer to the last part of the question is. I would hope that the answer is no, but I suspect that it is yes and that this is a fair sample of the sort of industrial relations practice that members of the extreme Right would implement should it get its puppet political party installed in power. We hear a good deal about freedom from members of the New Right or, as it is more accurately described, the extreme Right. A taste of the sort of freedom which would prevail should it achieve the political dominance it seeks is the freedom to sack anybody at 30 minutes notice.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is worth while commenting on or drawing attention to the fact that even the Sydney Daily Telegraph which, to say the least, is not a paper which normally adopts a sympathetic editorial line either to the Australian Labor Party or to the trade unions, said:
But it cannot be right to callously and contemptuously put 500 workers on the dole with only 30 minutes notice.

So Mr Copeman and those who sail with him have gone much too far even for a newspaper such as the Sydney Daily Telegraph, which is traditionally hostile to the Australian Labor Party and to the trade union movement. Indeed, this action demonstrates that, in what is seen as the utopia sought by some members of the H. R. Nicholls Society and supported by their lackeys in the Commonwealth Parliament, such as the Leader of the Opposition and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, there will be two classes of people-those who do the sacking and those who get the sack.

Finally, as with the earlier attempt by Mr Copeman and Peko-Wallsend to provoke industrial strife in the Pilbara, the action here is clearly politically motivated. It is not taken in the interests of the shareholders at Peko-Wallsend, the national economy or in the national interest. It is another provocative attempt by the extreme Right, supported as it is by the present leadership of the Liberal Party of Australia, whatever outright hostilities Steele Hall and other people have about it, and the motivation is not to best serve the interests of the company shareholders, the Australian economy, or the people of Australia in general. The motivation is clearly political.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Education confirm that the latest edition of Telecom's telephone directory for Perth lists an organisation called the Curtin University of Technology which apparently is located at Kent Street, Bentley, Western Australia? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the so-called Curtin University is in fact the Western Australian Institute of Technology? If so, is the Minister aware which responsible officer authorised this apparent renaming of the Institute? Can the Minister confirm that the Western Australian Institute of Technology is constituted pursuant to an Act of the Western Australian legislature, which specifically provides that the name of the Institute shall be the Western Australian Institute of Technology? Finally, can the Minister comment on the legal implications of what appears to be the unilateral renaming of the Western Australian Institute of Technology?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, I have been advised, that the latest edition of the Perth telephone directory, September 1986, contains an entry for the Curtin University of Technology, an institution which, as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, does not exist. It is worth noting that the same directory also contains a full list of entries for the Western Australian Institute of Technology, including its various components. Discussions with the Director of the Western Australian Post-Secondary Education Commission, the Western Australian body that deals with higher education matters, indicate that the entry would have been arranged by the Institution itself. Further checking with Telecom revealed that the request from WAIT would have been treated as a request for an additional entry and that, provided the request was in writing, it would have been processed in the routine way.

ANSWER.PARA: The Western Australian Institute of Technology, including its name, is authorised under the Western Australian Institute of Technology Act 1966 of Western Australia. That Act includes the name, powers and functions of the Institute. The Western Australian Minister for Education has publicly announced his intention to change the name of WAIT to the Curtin University of Technology. This change will require an amendment to the WAIT Act. Such amendments have not been introduced into the Western Australian Parliament. The WAPSEC advises that it is likely to happen before the end of the year, but it has not happened yet. Presumably the amendment to the WAIT Act would include the powers and functions appropriate to the Institute to be named the Curtin University of Technology.

As far as the Commonwealth is concerned, we have no powers with regard to the naming of those institutions, but I have made it clear to Bob Pearce, and indeed to Premier Burke, that the unilateral name change, which legally the State Government is entitled to make, will not carry with it any implications for increased funding as far as the Commonwealth is concerned. In conclusion, I hope that the Western Australian Government will reconsider its intentions with regard to the name change. The Western Australian Institute of Technology is a very successful institution. It has a very good national reputation and, indeed, a growing international reputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very entrepreneurial.

—It is very entrepreneurial, as Senator Chaney says. It is an institution that has moved very quickly into the field of export of education services, with our Government's support and encouragement. In my view, it has no need to seek a name change or a change of prestige. It has the prestige it has earned by its performance and, in our view, it ought to continue in that fashion.

—I am sure that Senator Hamer cannot seriously expect an answer to all those questions. If I did have answers to them-but I do not-I would divulge little, if any, of it anyway. —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of a proposed trial of Mr Doan Quoc Sy, a Vietnamese author, by a people's tribunal in Ho Chi Minh City for alleged crimes against the state? Is the Minister also aware of Amnesty International reports that Mr Sy has been held in detention for the past two years without trial and prior to his arrest had applied for, and was granted, a visa to Australia where his son and daughter now reside? Can the Minister inform the Senate what steps the Australian Government can take to secure the fair treatment of Mr Sy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The case of Doan Quoc Sy is one of two that have been brought to the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs in recent days and is one of a number of instances that have been giving rise to some concern about the human rights situation in Indo-China generally, and Vietnam in particular. Vietnam acceded to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights on 24 December 1982, which gives Vietnam clearly defined obligations to observe human rights principles. Mr Hayden took up human rights issues against that background with the Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, during the Vietnamese Foreign Minister's visit to Australia in March 1984 and again during Mr Hayden's visit to Vietnam in March 1985. He took these opportunities to raise a number of specific human rights cases. During his visit in 1985 he gave Mr Thach a letter which confirmed our understanding of Vietnam's undertakings on the matters discussed and requested further details on specific cases. The Australian Ambassador in Hanoi has been actively engaging in a continuing exchange on this issue with Vietnamese justice and foreign affairs ministry officials.

ANSWER.PARA: In recent days, as I have said, the Government has had two cases in particular brought to its attention-that of Chu Van Tan who is reported to be under threat of execution and the case that Senator Sibraa has raised of Doan Quoc Sy who, it is reported, is to be tried at the end of this month. The Australian Embassy has made inquiries about these two cases on a number of occasions and has been instructed to make further inquiries as a matter of urgency. I should say, finally, that we have no illusions about the extent of our influence in this area, but we feel we have established a basis for seeking some information from Vietnam. Mr Hayden has explained to the Vietnamese that one necessary condition of a satisfactory bilateral relationship is the need to be able to respond to Australian domestic concern on these issues in a factual and credible way.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY TRADING HOURS ORDINANCE

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to an article in Tuesday's Melbourne Herald reporting on a proposal by the Opposition spokesperson on local government and administrative services, Mr Wilson Tuckey, to sell off and lease back Commonwealth properties? If so, can the Minister indicate what would be the financial implications of this proposal if it were implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article in which Mr Tuckey is reported as having obtained a list of 22,000 Commonwealth properties which he has given to the Real Estate Industry Association. It includes communications stations, rifle ranges, telephone exchanges, car parks, light- houses and so on. I do not know whether the Opposition, should it become the government, intends to sell off all those things, but it will have to do something like that, of course, in order to offset the irresponsible taxation and expenditure policies that its Leader has been peddling. Either it will have to get a one-off gain of the order of $6 billion by flogging off lighthouses, car parks, Army camps and so on, or it will come in with a $10 billion deficit as Mr Howard was about to do when he was last booted out of office.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposition does have disturbing similarities, though a more extended proposition, to what came out of South Australia last year. The Leader of the South Australian Opposition, Mr Olsen, promised during the 1985 State election campaign that he would sell off the South Australian Oil and Gas Corporation Pty Ltd for three times its market value to pay for the rest of his program while at the same time saying he could retain control of the SAOGC in government hands and expand its oil and gas exploration activities.

Senator Foreman of course would be well aware of that undertaking given by Mr Olsen and the arithmetic sleight of hand that underpinned it. He would be equally well aware of the way it was received by the South Australian electorate. But Mr Tuckey proposes to go much further than that, so he says, apparently to obtain about $6 billion. The fact that the South Australian electorate passed judgment on Mr Olsen and his proposition in the way that it did and that the present Federal Opposition Leader is willing to tolerate in silence Mr Tuckey's proposition to expand greatly on that policy is a sign of the political acumen of the present Leader of the Opposition.

There is, of course, a sound case for property to be sold off for which the Commonwealth no longer has a use or is unlikely to have any use, and this Government has done so in every Budget since we have been in government. But to sell off the comprehensive list of Commonwealth property of the type identified by Mr Tuckey would be totally irresponsible. It is the sort of thing that one expects from Mr Tuckey. It is the sort of thing one expects to be sanctioned by the Leader of the Opposition, as it has been sanctioned by the Leader of the Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —Flogging assets to pay for the abolition of the assets test.

—Yes, flogging off government assets to pay for the abolition of the assets test. It further justifies, if any further justification was needed, the action that the Labor Party in Western Australia will take-that it is going to remove Mr Tuckey from the Parliament at the next election by directing Labor preferences against him.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Science aware of the concern expressed earlier this week by Mr Colin Norris, the Australian Government Analyst, on the imported food inspection program when he said that it was naive to believe that the States and the Territories could adequately cope, given their present resources, with the work which, up until recently, had been carried out by the Government analytical laboratories? Can the Minister advise whether adequate inspections are being carried out, whether the fears expressed by many people can be put to rest and whether the efficiency of the testing programs has been put at risk?
—I have not seen that complaint by Mr Norris. I do not have answer to the question. I will seek one from the Minister as quickly as possible.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Education. I refer to an article in today's Courier-Mail headed `Tertiary places up 560 but State's share cut'. Has the Minister noted the inconceivably negative way in which the newspaper has been critical of the Federal Government's efforts in providing new tertiary places in Queensland, even though the facts are that the 20 per cent of the new places Queensland will receive in 1987 is in excess of its proportion of the Australian population? Is it correct that, in the area of tertiary places, the Hawke Government has been discriminating in favour of Queensland? If so, should not a newspaper such as the Courier-Mail be positively highlighting this fact?

—Mr President, I rise on another point of order. I find it very strange that a question should be addressed to a Minister asking her for her opinion as to the way a newspaper should be presenting information. I suggest that that is drawing a very long bow indeed and is wasting the time of this Parliament. It has nothing to do with information that this Minister can give. She can merely give her artistic opinion or her sub-editorial opinion-call it what you will. I think this is a gross abuse of Question Time by a Deputy Chairman of this place who should know better.
—Mr President, speaking to the point of order: I think the point of order is not worthy of a person who is supposed to be the Leader of the Opposition in this place.
—Order! The response is clearly within the purview of the Minister. The question is in order.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think it is very important that Senator Colston has raised this question in this place at this time because the facts concerning our positive approach to higher education places in Queensland need to be restated. Unfortunately they need to be re- stated many times because it is the case that the Courier-Mail, for reasons that I cannot pretend to understand, repeatedly misrepresents the facts regarding the Hawke Government's provision of higher education places in Queensland. Those facts, as Senator Colston's question pointed out, are very favourable. It has been our policy since we first came into government to act to overcome the backlog in the shortage of places for higher education places in Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: When we came into government Queensland certainly was dragging behind other States in the number of higher education places it had available. But in each of our decisions allocating the extra higher education places that we have created, we have given Queensland more than its per capita share of places. It is our policy, often stated, to continue to do that until Queensland has caught up. In the legislation that was introduced yesterday, for example, Queensland will get 560 of the new 3,000 places which will be available for students throughout Australia next year-a very favourable outcome for Queensland. It it one we are happy about but, of course, we would be even happier if the Queensland Government and the Courier-Mail acknowledged the progress that we are making.

It is also true that one of the reasons for lower participation in higher education in Queensland than in other States is that it is a very decentralised State and it is difficult for students to travel from all over Queensland to higher education institutions. Acknowledging this difficulty, again we have acted in co-operation with the Queensland Government to provide higher education places in Cairns and Mackay. Places in Cairns will be provided next year in co-operation with the James Cook University and places in Mackay will be provided in co-operation with the Rockhampton Institute of Higher Education.

We are acting generously towards Queensland. We wish to do so. Any examination of the allocation of places in each of our budgetary years will show that Queensland has more than its per capita share. We will continue to do this because we recognise that when we came into government, Queensland was a long way behind. We are perfectly happy about this policy. Senator Colston is right to draw attention to it. We only hope now that the Queensland State Government and the Courier-Mail will acknowledge the facts of the matter.

What interest has been shown by Hong Kong businessmen in taking advantage of the Federal Government's business migration program? Is there any possibility of Tasmania's deriving any benefit from this scheme?

—As honourable senators will know, considerable interest has been shown by Hong Kong and other business men and women-in particular business women; I understand that the most important immigrant under the business migration program has been a woman-for many factors, among them being the desire of people to move out of that area and to live under stable and good government in this country, and the economic future of this country. For some months I have been watching with interest the development of a specialist clothing factory, in fact a swimwear producing factory, in Launceston, Tasmania. The Shun Man company has been developing a factory and bringing in machinery. It looks as though it will employ in excess of 100 people when the factory is in full production. It is due to open next month. Mr Bill Cheung, who came out under the business migration program, obviously has considerable faith in the economy of Australia and in the work force in Tasmania. He was Hong Kong's third largest specialist swimwear manufacturer. It is interesting that at a time-
—He chose a Liberal State, Senator.

He neglected to take into account that in every Budget-every one with which I have been associated, anyway, and that is, the last four, and, I expect, every Budget since the beginning of the Federation-there have been savings against Forward Estimates due to one-off savings on expenditure, deferrals of programs and slippage of programs. Finally, he grossly underestimated the sorts of profits that were likely to come from the Reserve Bank of Australia. In other words-and, in particular, bearing in mind from whom this analysis came-Mr McCarrey's analysis of the Commonwealth Budget was a very shoddy piece of work which displayed either professional incompetence or intellectual fraudulence.

Although Mr McCarrey currently holds a position with the Institute of Public Affairs, he has a long-standing record of being a hired gun for assorted Tory causes. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance as Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask whether the Minister recalls the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, saying a week before the 1984 Federal election:

QUESTION.PARA: We expect inflation will be less than five per cent in the year ahead, and we are determined to keep it below five per cent.

I ask whether the Minister recalls the Prime Minister saying in Tokyo on 16 May of this year that the Government's policies are `expected to produce a sharp decline in our inflation rate in coming quarters, beginning with the current June quarter'. I also ask whether the Minister recalls the Treasurer saying recently, indeed, on 25 July:
We believe that the Australian inflation rate will continue to decline as the Government's policies take their effect in the economy.

Is it a fact that the inflation rate in Australia has risen in each of the last three quarters, is now running at an annual rate of 8.9 per cent and is continuing to rise, and is five times higher than that of our major trading partners? When will the Government adopt policies to reverse this disastrous trend rather than fuelling it as its current policies are doing?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assertion in the last part of the question is absolutely wrong. It is not Government policies which have caused the Australian inflation rate to increase. The direct cause of the increase in the inflation rate is the devaluation of the Australian dollar which, in turn, has been caused by the collapse of export prices.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is evident that there are still some members of the Opposition who are sufficiently ignorant to believe that inflation in Australia is being driven by wages. The fact is that in Australia real wages have declined in recent years because of, firstly, the Medicare effect and, secondly, an explicit wage discount. If the Government's objectives set in this Budget are achieved, real wages will decline again this year. We have the paradox where real wages in Australia are falling, and the consumer price index rate of increase has accelerated, it is true. A number of other countries have had massive real wage increases-like the United Kingdom, for example, which practises the industrial relations policy which the Opposition supports, in spite of an unemployment rate above 13 per cent. There have been real wage increases in excess of 10 per cent in the last three years; whereas in Australia, with high rates of growth and falling unemployment, in the same period real wages have fallen. They needed to fall because the wages explosion that occurred in the last two years that John Howard was Treasurer had to be cancelled out.

ANSWER.PARA: As to what I said in 1984, that I expected the inflation rate to come down below 5 per cent in the coming year-I think it did come down to 5 per cent-it has accelerated since then. The cause, as I said before, has been the devaluation of the Australian dollar, caused in turn by the collapse of export prices. It is regrettable, but it is true, that the CPI increase for this quarter is the highest quarterly CPI increase since John Howard was Treasurer, and that the annual rate for the quarter ended September has reached 8.9 per cent, which is regrettably high, as the Government concedes, but very much lower than the 11.5 per cent which it was when John Howard ceased to be Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his Pontius Pilate answer, but I ask a supplementary question. He listed a whole series of circumstances which he said put this all beyond the Government's control. I ask him. In what way have circumstances changed since 25 July this year when the Treasurer said: `We believe that the Australian inflation rate will continue to decline'? What changes have occurred since that time to cause the Treasurer's prediction to be proven so grievously wrong?

—The Government did not foresee two years ago the devaluation of the Australian dollar which has subsequently occurred. We did not foresee that because we did not foresee the collapse in commodity prices. Perhaps we should be held culpable for not foreseeing the most disastrous collapse in commodity prices and Australian export prices which has happened since World War II. If we are culpable for not foreseeing that, well, so be it. As for the Treasurer's comments in July, I think that the context in which they were stated was an annual rate of inflation and not a quarterly rate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(1) Resolves that United Nations General Assembly Resolution 3379 (XXX) which equates Zionism with racism-
(a) has been unhelpful in the context of the search for a settlement in the Middle East;
(b) is inconsistent with the Charter of the United Nations;
(c) remains unacceptable as a misrepresentation of Zionism; and
(d) has served to escalate religious animosity and incite anti-semitism
(2) Recommends that the Government lend support to efforts to overturn Resolution 3379 (XXX) in the United Nations.
I seek leave to have the accompanying speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

I move this Resolution from a conviction, which I believe will be shared by all Australians who value truth, fairness and tolerance, that the equation of Zionism with racism is profoundly wrong, disruptive and unacceptable.

United Nations General Assembly Resolution 3379, adopted in 1975, which sought to make this equation, has been regarded by successive Australian Governments as unacceptable. In moving this Resolution in the Parliament, the Government hopes for bi-partisan support so that the voice of Australia can be added to those of others in the international community who wish to see this deeply regrettable expression of United Nations opinion overturned.
Madam Speaker
To suggest that Zionism is racism is, first of all, a blatant distortion of the truth.

This is not the place to give a history of the development of Zionism. I would, however, refer all Honourable Members who wish to inform themselves on this to the outstanding address by my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, to the Zionist Federation of Australia on 13 April under the title, ``Israel: A Contemporary Democratic Socialist Perspective''.
Mr Hayden outlined the idealism and the enlightened, emancipatory principles which went into the foundation of the State of Israel.
As well, he referred to the terrible impact of the Holocaust on the Zionist movement.

In the month in which the award to Elie Wiesel of the Nobel Peace Prize has reminded us all of the monstrous racial oppression suffered by the Jewish people less than 50 years ago, the characterisation of Zionism as racism is a particular offence to decency and logic, not only to our Jewish community, but to all Australians.
Apart from its distortion of reality, Resolution 3379 has become an obstacle to the search for a settlement in the Middle East, difficult as that already is.

In a region where insecurity and suspicion are strong, where barriers between peoples have proved difficult to break down, it is highly counter-productive to insult the guiding philosophy of a people, especially one whose consciousness has been seared by the scourge of anti-semitism.
Resolution 3379 has not advanced the interests of those who promoted it. It has done nothing to solve the plight of the Palestinian people.

Successive Australian Governments have believed that there can be no peace in the Middle East until the Palestinian problem is resolved justly and peacefully and with the agreement of all those involved.

This Government's support for the overturning of Resolution 3379 is based on our continued desire to see a peaceful, just and lasting solution to the Middle East dispute. Diversions such as Resolution 3379 serve only to distract and disrupt efforts towards this end.
The Resolution has done very real damage to the relations between States. It has also harmed the credibility and reputation of the United Nations.

The United Nations was intended to promote peace and harmony between the peoples of the world. It has the primary task of maintaining international peace and also promoting the goal of encouraging respect for human rights.

Resolution 3379 was clearly not an attempt to further those purposes and principles. It had the effect of unfairly isolating a member state of the United Nations and, in so doing, was contrary to the spirit of the Charter.

There is no country which is more committed to upholding the reputation and effectiveness of the UN than Australia. Our performance as a member of the Security Council over the past two years is the most recent evidence of this commitment.

Along with other countries, we have fought to maintain international support, including, very importantly, financial support, for the United Nations and its Specialised Agencies-the ILO, UNESCO and others. Our task has been made immeasurably more difficult in view of the disaffection felt for the UN in recent years by such countries as the United States. The passage of Resolution 3379 was an important factor in producing this disaffection.

Over the past two years or so, increasing international attention has been given to the question of removing this unacceptable Resolution from the United Nations record. President Chaim Herzog, the widely respected President of Israel, who will pay a State visit to Australia next month, has been a leading figure in this process.

The Australian Jewish community has consulted closely with the Government, particularly the Minister for Foreign Affairs, on the matter in recent months in order to determine what influence Australia might bring to bear.

Realistically, we must acknowledge that it would be counter-productive to initiate a move in the United Nations at this stage to overturn Resolution 3379. There still would not be the support necessary to ensure the success of such a move.
Indeed, the opposite result might be achieved: countries which may have come to question their original position on the Resolution might be forced once again to line up behind it.

Nevertheless, the world political climate is changing and there are grounds for belief that an expression of the Australian Parliament's view, along the lines I have outlined, could contribute to that change.
In taking this step, Madam Speaker, it is, I believe, important to emphasise that the Australian Government's position on the Middle East remains unchanged.

As I have indicated, we believe that a resolution of the Palestinian question is central to any Middle East settlement. The Government acknowledges the right of self-determination for the Palestinian people, including the right, if they so choose, to independence and the possibility of their own independent state. We recognise that whatever arrangements are finally settled upon will depend on decisions involving the participation and agreement of all parties concerned.
We remain fundamentally committed to the security of Israel and its right to exist within secure and recognised boundaries in accordance with Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338.

It is in the interests of helping to achieve a peaceful, just and lasting solution to the Middle East dispute, one which has the acceptance of all sides, that I commend the resolution I have introduced to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
