SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion strikes at the very heart of the Government's major failures. The Government has boasted of its record of lowering inflation, of bringing about strong economic growth and rising employment and lowering the number of industrial disputes. The Government has also claimed that its steel and car plans have been evidence of its outstanding success in a similar way. The reality is totally different. For example, today we have had further evidence that this lower inflation rate that has been promised and boasted about has not eventuated and today's figures confirm that Australia's relative inflation rate compared with those of our trading partners is the worst ever for which we have records. It is the worst ever, relative to our trading partners. That is a great `success' for this Government and we see a similar sort of `success' when we look at a whole range of the Government's empty boasts and its disgraceful promises all of which have been broken.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government boasted about rising employment but now we are seeing massive and continuing increases in unemployment. What about lower levels of industrial dispute? Today figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics reveal that the number of working days lost in the 12 months to July of this year is the highest in a 12-month period since the 12 months ending March 1984-in other words, in this Government's first year in office. So industrial disputation is on the way up. Across the whole range of its promises this Government has made a mess of things.

What mess has it made in the steel and car plan? That mess is basically the same as the mess it has made across the whole range of its promises because that mess depends on the Government's inability to face up to the union leadership. It has been caused by a subservience to certain key members of the industrial wing of the Australian Labor Party. Of course, the ALP is the political wing of the Labor movement and it receives its instructions from that industrial wing. Because of that subservience, the Government has given in over a whole range of areas and this has resulted in its failures. When the going gets tough the Government, which is led by a former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, always gives in to the present President of the ACTU. In the steel and car plans we can see again this failure to bring about the basic fundamental changes in industrial relations attitudes, without which there can be no success for either of these industry plans and therefore no ultimate success for either of these industries, both of which depend on the Australian taxpayers for their support. They need government assistance for their particular schemes to help them through difficult periods.

These plans could have worked and in fact at one stage they looked as though they were working. The steel industry plan was going very well, productivity was rising and industrial unrest was falling. Profits were going up in the steel making industry. Now this is all being put at serious risk by industrial disruption, by a refusal to give up outdated and ludicrous work practices.
Steel and Car Plans

The same situation exists in the car industry. This industry may have been saved by the Government's car industry plan had it not been for the Government's own activities in other areas, along with growing industrial unrest. The car industry plan was sabotaged by this Government itself, with its nonsensical anti-business taxes which have hit the car industry probably harder than any other. A confidential report on the automotive industry forecasts that vehicle production in Australia this year will fall to just over 328,000 units. It states:
This is the lowest level since the 1961 recession when production fell to 231,000 . . . On current production rates the industry faces layoffs.

Here we have it. The car industry is in crisis not because of the car industry plan but despite it; it is in crisis because of the Government's other actions, because of its other deliberate policies which attack the motor vehicle industry. To make matters worse, we have the current superannuation claim involving strike action by unions. That has prompted General Motors-Holden's Ltd to say that the future of the motor vehicle industry is being jeopardised by the industrial action of unions over superannuation claims, and as a result 2,500 workers have had to be stood down. What was the response of the Minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), when this matter was raised yesterday by Senator Messner? He said he very much regretted the fact that General Motors had to stand down workers as a result of superannuation. He said, quite correctly:
It is the sort of thing . . . that this country cannot afford in the future.
For his advice, it cannot afford it now, either. He continued:
The Government has been having a series of negotiations with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and with others to try to bring about a resolution of the superannuation issue.

So here we have an admission from the Government that its existing arrangements cannot and have not worked in providing the sort of industrial relations climate in which the industry can get itself out of trouble. It is having to have further talks with the Australian Council of Trade Unions to see what it is allowed to do. The same thing applied when Senator Button responded to Senator Chaney yesterday on steel. Senator Chaney pointed to the dramatic increase in industrial disruption. At the Port Kembla steel works alone it rose by 680 per cent in the second half of the last financial year. Senator Button's response to Senator Chaney's question on what action the Government would take was:
. . . it is basically a matter for the companies and the work force to address . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that right or not, Senator? Do you say that it is not right? You do not know what you are talking about.

—I am glad the Minister interjects. Here we have a situation where the Government has never had such powerful clout in bringing about a reasonable industrial relations climate, and it cannot use that clout effectively because it is so subservient to the ACTU leadership. I shall quote from the Steel Industry Authority report. It states that the Government has arranged an `accord'. I use that terrible word; it is the Minister's own word. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Accord between BHP and the Unions it was agreed that both parties would comply with established dispute settlement procedures to reduce the incidence of disruption leading to the loss of wages and production.

How did this accord come about? It came about because the Government sought an accord as a condition of its assistance. It seems to me that when the Minister protests in the extraordinary way that he did just now, he is forgetting that there is no point in the Government trying to bail out the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, the car industry or anyone else by protecting them if under that protection all that happens is that the unions demand a bigger slice of the cake and continue with the industrial disruption which has destroyed the competitive advantage and economic stability that the Government has been seeking to give to this industry at public expense. I think the figure last year for bounties totalled $21m.

I am certainly not opposed to the steel industry plan; on the contrary. The Government's failure was not in trying to do the right thing; it failed because of its spineless approach to industrial relations and because of its continual subservience to the ACTU leadership and the leadership of some of the more left wing unions. In fact, that left wing is strong enough to have pushed one of its more outspoken leaders on to the Senate ticket in Victoria ahead of the Minister at the table. That subservience to union pressure is undoing the specific benefits that should have come to this industry, and saved it, from schemes that did at one stage have quite a lot going for them. I commend the Minister at the table for his efforts in creating the steel industry plan. As he knows, a large amount of input came before he was the Minister, but he picked up the ball that was passed to him very well. While I commend the Minister for his efforts in getting this industry back on its feet, I say to him that the Government of which he is a party, and which he supports, by its own actions is undoing that good.

Let us have a look at the reality of what has happened. The steel industry report which was tabled in the Senate this week has revealed that in Port Kembla, in particular, where more than half of Australia's steel is produced, worsening industrial disputes, inadequate productivity and unsatisfactory management and work practices could put the Government's steel industry plan in jeopardy. Let us remember that a former President of the ACTU, Cliff Dolan, is one of the members of that Steel Industry Authority. The slap at management practices as well as work practices in that report is clearly an endeavour to be what could be described as even-handed. How remarkable it is that the same management does not have this level of industrial unrest, does not have this falling productivity at the Newcastle steel works. Why does Port Kembla? Has it got different management practices, or is the reality the simple fact that the Federated Ironworkers Association in Port Kembla is a left wing branch run by left wingers, whereas the union overall in New South Wales is a much more moderate and responsible one?

It will be interesting to see whether the membership of the ironworkers union in Port Kembla at its elections next month decides whether it wants to go down this crazy track of industrial disruption and falling productivity, as has occurred in Port Kembla, or whether it wants to follow a far more responsible attitude which will guarantee the security of jobs, as has been the case at Newcastle. That is basically the very point that emerges out of the Steel Industry Authority's report. In today's Illawarra Mercury the local Federated Ironworkers Association branch secretary, Mr Lelli, complained bitterly that I had somehow gained access to these figures before he had. In other words, he was complaining that the truth had been released in the Steel Industry Authority's statement before being presented to the union, the ACTU or anyone else, and could not be censored the way other material has been censored when it has gone to the Economic Planning Advisory Council and subsequently has not been released because of the imposition of control over information. Fortunately, Mr Lelli's hope that he would be advised of this first have been defeated. The Steel Industry Authority made its report, and it is a damning one.

The report reveals that industrial disruption at Port Kembla increased by more than 680 per cent in the six months to June this year. This lifted total man hours lost at Port Kembla to 124,774 in the latest six months. That is about four times the level at the Newcastle steelworks. It means that man hours lost per employee have increased at Port Kembla by 211 per cent between June 1984 and June 1986, lifting the total to 10.9 hours per employee. This rise in man hours lost is six times as large as the average increase in man hours lost per employee in the overall metal manufacturing industry. Its present level of 2.7 man hours lost is only about a quarter of the size of the loss at the Port Kembla steelworks. The Steel Industry Authority, in its report, describes the increasing trend of industrial disputes at Port Kembla as alarming and it says that the agreement under the steel industry plan to comply with established dispute-settlement procedures `has not been followed over the last six months of the year, particularly at Port Kembla'. As a result the Authority stated that it:
. . . sought the intervention of the ACTU and drew the attention of the unions concerned to their obligations under the Steel Industry Plan.

I say to the Minister, Senator Button: There is the response. The Steel Industry Authority itself says that the unions have an obligation under the steel industry plan to behave responsibly. The Minister's own Authority clearly states--

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said it myself in here.

—If the Minister has said it himself in here, why does he bother interjecting in that asinine way when I am making the point that there is a responsibility on this Government to ensure that industrial relations proceed in a proper and coherent way? There is no point in the Minister going back to the bad old days and saying: `Under your Government it was worse'. That is the only response that this Government ever makes. The question is: Is it realistic for the Minister to claim success for this steel industry plan when the key element of that plan, which is increased productivity, is now being hit by industrial disruption?
—Quote the figures for productivity.

—I certainly will. I am glad that the Minister asked me to quote the figures for productivity. I thank him for his dorothy dix role in this matter. Let us have a look at the productivity figures. As I said earlier in my speech, initially they began to improve. What happened at Port Kembla in the six months to June this year as against the six months to December? Productivity had increased to 291 tonnes of raw steel per employee per annum and it then fell to 266 tonnes. That represents an increase over the whole of the steel industry plan of less than 3 per cent. The 3 per cent increase in productivity at Port Kembla is a dramatic success for Senator Button. No wonder he is blushing and looking down at his papers. What a nonsensical claim for the Minister to make! There has been a fall from 291 tonnes to 266 tonnes of raw steel per employee per annum in the last six months, yet Senator Button feels confident and happy about the great success of his steel industry plan in Port Kembla.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that productivity has increased in Newcastle where there are better industrial relations. The dramatic difference is that where one has decent industrial relations, one gets increased productivity. In Newcastle, the productivity, which had been much lower than in Port Kembla back in June 1984-it had been 238 tonnes as against Port Kembla's 259 tonnes of raw steel per employee per year-has risen in the latest two months of this financial year to just under 350 tonnes per worker per year, which is the target set by the Minister's plan. The significance, and the whole thrust of this debate, is that where there are proper and reasonable industrial relations, one can achieve these targets. Where there is failure, one cannot. The failure relates directly to industrial relations and outmoded work practices. The whole thrust of this debate is that the Government's failure was not in terms of the scheme; the Government's failure has been in bringing out an appropriate industrial relations climate in which success can take place.

The extent to which this failure is damaging has only begun to be seen. As the company has come out with increased profits, there will be increasing pressure on it for higher wages. We will see more and more industrial unrest as the steel plan goes on-it has 2 1/2 years to go-and I believe that we face a worsening problem particularly as there will be an 8 per cent fall in domestic sales of steel in the current financial year.

The sorts of problems that we are having in the steel industry and in the car industry can be directly attributed to the subservience of the Government when troubles arise relating to union activities, to work practices in particular, and to irresponsible industrial unrest. These plans could have worked; that, I believe, is the tragedy. As I have said, the Government has no better opportunity to impose the concept of an accord than it has now. Even in this situation, where it controls the purse strings, it has been unable to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support the Opposition's matter of public importance concerning the car and steel plans. Our assessment of the plans is that they have worked reasonably well. They may not be the ultimate in industry planning but we believe that they are enlightened attempts by the Government to come to terms with the problems in the industry. I say to Opposition senators that the steel industry plan in particular has been successful. Steel was the problem area of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd in the early 1980s and it is set next year to be the company's largest profit-making sector. It is beyond doubt that the steel plan has been successful. BHP is now the second most profitable steel company in the world. The Australian Financial Review, not a paper that is noted for applauding government interventionist policies, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The steel plan is a big success.

I speak as chairman of a company that runs one of the only two steel mills outside BHP. I believe that I have some inside knowledge of what goes on in the steel industry. I hasten to say that our company has received no help whatsoever from the Government in the running of its steel operation, nor has it sought it; I mention it only to alert the Senate to my intimate involvement in the steel industry.

Senator Michael Baume criticised the Government essentially on three points. He raised the question of inflation. I do not know what that has to do with the steel plan that we are debating. He then got on to the question of disputes, and he cited a few figures-very unfairly. Let us have a look at the dispute problem in the steel industry. There is no doubt that there have been some industrial relations problems of late; however, we see that disputes are still at a very low level if we look at the figures objectively. The drop in disputes in the last financial year relates mainly to the day of protest earlier this year when the national wage case was delayed.

There have been some problems at Port Kembla, which Senator Michael Baume concentrated upon. It is unfortunate that the Federated Iron-workers Association of Australia ignored the dispute settling procedures incorporated in the steel plan, and this is to be deplored. However, as to the strike figures at Port Kembla, I believe that Senator Baume's figures were very stilted because they went back only two years. In the year to May 1986 there were only 0.66 per cent of shifts lost, whereas in the year 1980 the figure was 2.77 per cent of shifts lost. There has been a dramatic improvement over what was the norm in the industry when the Liberals were in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to look at it per employee.

—The number of employees has dropped significantly, so that factor would not alter substantially the figures that I have just quoted. The Democrats support the concept of a steel industry plan. We think it is the right way to go with industry assistance, and we would like to see this type of assistance extended to other industries. It is, we believe, a very enlightened approach. The debate on industry protection in this country has been hopelessly narrow. We hear of free trade versus protection; tariffs or no tariffs has been the issue. This, I would say, is very largely the result of ideologues and free marketeers who wish to ensure that their ideas retain dominance in the Government and in the bureaucracy. They wish to ignore the policy initiatives of creative intervention by governments. They want the Government to focus purely on the question of whether there should be tariffs. The argument is much more complicated than the simple question of tariffs versus free trade. In fact free trade does not exist in the modern world; it never has existed. We must protect our industries, and we must encourage them by whatever means is appropriate if we are not to be swamped by subsidised imports. That is a fact of life. I do not believe it is open to reasonable dispute.

SPEECH.PARA: The important question is: What sort of protection should we give out industries? It is around that which the debate should be revolving. The free traders have the upper hand at the moment, principally because of the inappropriate protection that industry has been given over the last 45 years. Our system of protection could better be described as patronage. It has not really been protection at all. Successive governments have built up tariff barriers around an inward looking Australian industry-largely an inefficient manufacturing industry. We have not had the political will or clout to do anything about it until this time. We built up tariff walls with no regard to what went on behind them. Once internationalisation of the world economy took over, particularly in the late 1960s, our antiquated, inefficient industrial infrastructure could not cope. Our geographical isolation was no longer protecting us, and our industries were so inefficient that even massive tariff protection could not really protect them. Foreign firms closed their subsidiaries in Australia and started to import from highly efficient plants in Asia and Europe, and our local industries just went to the wall; they were closed down.

Tariffs by themselves have failed to protect our industries. The argument about free markets and dropping protection has largely been propagated by the transnational corporations which are trying to push their own barrows, to tear down the tariff barriers and let industry stand or fall on its own merits. That, of course, is a disastrous course of action to adopt. Unfortunately, there are very many elements in the Government, the bureaucracy and the Opposition which seem to be hell-bent on this course of tearing down all protection for industry. The textile, clothing and footwear industries are likely to be the next victims of the free market dogma.

However, we want to give credit where credit is due. The Democrats, and I in particular, believe that the steel plan is the most innovative piece of industry policy ever introduced in this country. I cannot praise what has happened more highly than that. The plan does not just give protection to BHP. It sought commitments from BHP to increase productivity and to increase investment. That surely is the way to go when we are trying to develop our industries. In moving to assist industries, the Government should seek to ensure that increases in productivity and investment are also made as consideration for the help that the Government would afford an industry. In addition, the BHP bounty protection will guarantee it 80 per cent of the Australian market. Particularly, there was a fast track system of protection from dumping. I would like to see that sort of approach applied much more generally-where there is a quid pro quo between government and industry, where there is co-operation between industry and government and where government seeks commitments from unions to change work practices.

BHP, for its part, made a commitment to invest $800m over five years. This figure looks like being very well and truly overrun. The investment, undoubtedly, will be higher than that. Pledges were made on increasing productivity, and they will be easily achieved also. The unions have been asked to make commitments on work practices and to follow different dispute procedures and pay demands. These very largely have been agreed to. In effect, the Government has said: `We will give you some protection on the basis that the company and the workers give a commitment on productivity'. It is not a one way street and it has led to a dramatic success in Australia in the steel industry. If the free marketeers had won the day, and all sorts of help, government assistance and intervention in the steel industry had not been forthcoming, and if there had not been the creative intervention, our industry would not have been able to expand at a time when the Japanese, Koreans, Americans and Europeans are all cutting back on their industries.

There is still a long way to go. The unions have not attacked some of the hard-core work practices yet. Let us hope that will be achieved in the years remaining in the plan. I believe the success of the steel industry plan has demonstrated what can be achieved if there is a willingness to intervene in the management of industry in this country and if management, government and the unions create a co-operative structure.

From the Opposition we heard nothing but criticism. I wonder what its steel plan would be. I wonder what it would have done to help the steel industry if it had been faced with the problem in 1980. The Opposition continually argues that governments should not intervene in the market-place; let the market forces reign supreme and everything will come right. On the industrial relations front, the Opposition has the hero-worship of Mr Charles Copeman and other industrialists who are champions of confrontation. I wonder what sort of steel industry we would have now if the Opposition's policies on industrial relations and non-intervention had been the order of the day in dealing with the problems in the steel industry in the early 1980s.
I turn now to the car industry. In talking about that plan, which has not yet been as successful as the steel industry plan, I go to section 9 of the Government's motor vehicle policy. It says:
The Government desires to see greater Australian participation in ownership and control in all sectors of the industry . . .

This is about the only reference I have seen-I am sorry that Senator Button is not in the chamber at the moment-by the Government to the desirability of Australian ownership in industry. It is a great pity that it has not acted on these sentiments. Last year we saw further domination by foreign interests of the car industry when the New Zealand interest, Ariadne, took over Repco, which was a very important supplier to the automotive industry, and then proceeded to split it up and sell off the assets. This would not have happened if the Government had been prepared to stand by its statement of its desirability for a greater degree of Australian ownership in the car industry.

However, in concept the plan is good. Remarkably, it followed a plan that I outlined on behalf of the Democrats some four or five years ago and for which I was criticised roundly in the South Australian Parliament. The car plan has four aims: To give industry time to modernise and restructure, and we would have to agree with that; to increase its efficiency, certainly; to hold down prices; and to reduce job losses in the short term. It says bravely-I give Senator Button full credit for this-it wants cut down the number of models from 13 to six. That is only common sense. That was the aspect of my suggestion for the car industry that was so roundly criticised in South Australia. The Government is prepared to allocate $150m over five years for an Australian design and research. My only criticism of that would be that it is a meagre amount if the Government is really serious about getting an Australian designed car off the ground. It is certainly moving in the right direction. It wants a gradual reduction in tariffs. Certainly the protection that the motor car industry has at the moment is unsustainable. It has quota protection of about 80 per cent and over 50 per cent tariff protection. That is unsustainable and indefensible by any standards.

The Government is planning to phase out quota protection by 1992; encourage exports with import credit systems; and guarantee a local content of 84 per cent. These are good initiatives. I believe they are steps in the right direction. It is a very difficult industry because it has been fragmented and it is foreign dominated, but the Government's aims are in the right direction. I believe they need to be more aggressively pursued. The Government needs to put the hard word on industry to do something about work practices and to do something about efficiency in return for, perhaps, greater assistance from the Government. That is the enlightened approach to industry protection today and the one that should be pursued.

Most of the strikes in the automotive industry have been related to superannuation. It is regrettable that the Government's superannuation initiative has got off on the wrong foot. It has created a lot of industrial problems and will create more unless the Government moves to do something about bringing in legislation to ensure that the guidelines it laid down are adhered to. There was a big strike at Borg Warner (Australia) Ltd earlier this year which resulted in 7,000 workers in the industry being laid off. It showed that unions and management must be able to co-operate if they are to adopt the just in time production methods that have been so successfully used in Japan and the Japanese car industry.

General Motors-Holden's Ltd is starting to export motors successfully from Australia and Toyota is exporting engine parts to its plant in Japan. Moves are taking place. The industry is working in the right direction, but I believe the Government has got to have a stronger will and a firmer hand in moving the industry to efficiency more quickly than has happened in the past. Let us contrast the industrial relations problems in Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd with General Motors-Holden's, for instance. I have often advocated in this place the importance of co-operation between management and the workers. I need to quote only one figure to illustrate how important this is to the Japanese industry. In 1986 Toyota received 1.9 million suggestions from its employees-that is about 100 employee suggestions per employee per year and 95 per cent of those 1.9 million suggestions from employees were acted on by management. Any organisation that can embrace co-operation with employees where they are prepared to use their brain power in the eight hour working day to improve the efficiency of the industry in which they are working-if it can get that environment going in this country-will win every time.

To its credit, the Ford Motor Co. has attempted to do this. My criticism of what Ford is doing is that it is introducing these schemes but it is not, at the same time, introducing profit sharing schemes. So the suggestions and the co-operative attitude it is trying to engender are, in fact, also moving to the point where the rewards, the dollars, are being shared with the work force. I believe if Ford does not do this it opens itself up widely to the criticism by the unions that it is introducing cosmetic schemes to get the workers to help and co-operate, but its workers are still missing out on sharing the rewards. That is a criticism that I think will be levelled in Australian industry and in the automotive industry unless there is a move by the manufacturers to share the dollars and to bring in some sort of incentive scheme.

I believe that we do have in the steel industry and automotive industry the most enlightened industry policy that we have ever seen in this country. My only fundamental criticism is that it is not moving quickly enough; it is not moving with enough effort, and the Government is not putting enough resources behind the initiatives that have been laid down. We have got to get away from saying that we just need tariffs and quotas. The Government has got to move to make sure that our industries are internationally competitive and are as efficient as any in the world. If the Japanese can do it, why cannot Australians? Why cannot Australians have an automotive industry that can export all around the world? Why can we not design and produce motor cars in this country that are world leaders in their class? There is no reason at all. It is just that we have got to have the will, but we must have co-operation with industry, with government and with management. Our work practices are critical to this. Our work practices will only be reformed by co-operation.

The confrontation that Senator Michael Baume so warmly advocates as a supporter of the New Right will never, ever succeed in reforming our work practices in this country. It cannot succeed; it will not succeed. It is not a new idea. It is not the New Right; it is the old Right, if you like, coming up with ideas that were around this country 100 years ago, dressed up in new clothing. That is not the way to go. Co-operation is the way to go. Creative intervention by governments in industry policy is what has to happen. We have got to get away from the dogma of the radical free marketeers. We should not sit back and let market forces run our country. That will not work. It is a recipe for disaster. Unless we have more of the creative intervention that at least these two plans sought to implement-very successfully in the steel industry and potentially successfully in the car industry-our industries will never be internationally competitive and never earn the export dollars they must earn if our country is to be saved from bankruptcy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. Senator Michael Baume, who introduced this matter of public importance, has so much interest in it that he left the chamber as soon as he had finished speaking.
—He'll be back.

—The honourable senator is trying to frighten me. He will be back, will he? I hope he comes as soon as possible because I would like him to hear a thing or two. What Senator Michael Baume is advocating in this place about industrial relations is the sort of view which was expressed by one of the great heroes in the Liberal Party of Australia, Mr Charles Copeman, who spent last weekend in the company of John Howard watching a fashion parade when Liberal Party wives acted as mannequins. It was a fashion parade of imported fashions. Mr Copeman was sitting next to Mr Howard a day after he had sacked 550 people without notice from the Besco Battery factory in Sydney owned by Peko-Wallsend Ltd. That is the sort of regime which is being sought by the Liberals in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to spend much time on what Senator Michael Baume had to say. I will come back to that. His speech reminded me very much of a conversation burped out over a long tax deductible lunch at Patrick Partners. That is not the sort of thing which contributes to constructive debate in a place like this. I want to talk about what Senator Siddons said because he made some very constructive contributions. I would like, if I may, to correct him on one or two points regarding the automotive industry plan.

It is true, as Senator Siddons said, that the Government expressed a view about Australian ownership of motor vehicle companies at the time of the introduction of the car plan. That is still our view. Senator Siddons said that the only thing that happened was that Repco, an Australian company, had been taken over by a New Zealand company and that was a very unfortunate thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —New Zealand interests, I said.

—New Zealand interests, yes. At a certain point, I would have agreed with the honourable senator about that. But those New Zealand interests then went on to sell their major automotive component divisions of Repco to a company called Automotive Components Ltd. It was a management buy out by a very good, competent group of Australian managers.
—That is one section of it only.

—A very substantial section. There is not much left in the old Repco empire. That new company has had a very good first quarter. It is a company committed to the industry and the industry is very glad about the changes which have taken place. I am not saying we can take credit for them, but all is well that ends well, I suppose, and one can be grateful for that. Last night I met with the Federated Automotive Component Manufacturers at their annual conference in Canberra. The component sector of the vehicle manufacturing industry was at loggerheads with the manufacturers when this plan was put in place. There is an enormous improvement in morale, in outward orientation and in attitudes to technology. I do not have to say those things. They were all said last night by people other than me. That is a very encouraging sign.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Siddons also referred to design money. It is not just for vehicles; it is also for components. Awards of design money have been made to a new technology steering wheel company in Sydney and other component manufacturers. It is a very good catalyst for change. I just remind honourable senators that it is true to say that the automotive industry in Australia-Toyota, Nissan and so on-has experts not only of engine components; in 1988 the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd will export 30,000 vehicles from Australia. That will be the first major export of vehicles from Australia since 1965, and it is something that is very much welcomed.

I return very briefly to Senator Michael Baume's speech which, if I may say so, was founded on ignorance. The things which stick in Senator Baume's craw are those which have provoked this rather flatteringly worded matter of public importance. The Liberals are saying in this MPI that the steel plan and the motor vehicle plan have been eminently successful, as their spokesmen have said month after month in this place; they have admitted it. But Opposition members now say: `Hurrah! There have been a couple of industrial disputes and now we can condemn those plans on the basis of industrial disputation. Joy oh joy! TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 259th report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled `Department of Community Services-Proposal to Acquire Computing Facilities'.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Report 259 presents the findings of the Committee's examination of a proposal by the Department of Community Services to acquire a distributed computing capability. The proposal was referred to the Committee under the terms of its standing reference to investigate and report on proposed acquisitions of Automatic Data Processing facilities by Commonwealth departments and authorities staffed under the Public Service Act 1922. The proposal by the Department of Community Services was estimated to cost approximately $20m for hardware and system software over 3 years and a further $6.1m per annum for other costs. The Committee identified several major areas of concern in the Department's initial submission which were not allayed by the Department's supplementary submission, sought by the Committee to address these matters. The Committee's primary concerns continue to relate to: First, the definition of the system requirements. The individual applications proposed to be automated have not been examined for their cost effectiveness and have not been assigned priorities, and the estimate of computer capacity requirements appears excessive. Secondly, in respect of options for meeting system requirements: The Department has given serious consideration only to its preferred option of a distributed computing capability; insufficient consideration has been given to a range of options between the centralised and distributed options which might meet the Department's requirements at less cost; and no serious consideration has been given to less ambitious but potentially more cost effective options which exclude automation of low priority applications.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, with regard to option costs: Costs appear to have been understated for all options, particularly for the preferred option of a distributed computing capability; the understated costs have biased the proposal in favour of a distributed system; and should the Department proceed to acquire a distributed computing capability of the capacity proposed there is a likelihood of cost over-runs. The Committee concluded that the Department's preferred option has not been satisfactorily justified on cost effectiveness grounds. The Committee concluded that there are several other less ambitious, less costly and potentially more cost effective options which the Department should seriously evaluate in greater detail before finalising its procurement proposals.

The Committee's consideration of this proposal by the Department of Community Services has differed from the scrutiny given other proposals under the Committee's standing reference in that it did not include a public hearing. The Committee has in its review of previous ADP acquisition proposals found that repeated attempts to elicit satisfactory answers and information from proponent departments have generally not justified the associated time and effort expended by the Committee. The Committee will in future be taking the view that if initial submissions are not satisfactory, and the subsequent communication of the Committee's concerns to the proponent department does not elicit a satisfactory response, the Committee will report its views to Parliament without further delay.

The Committee has decided in this case to present its views in a short report to Parliament to enable the Department of Community Services to respond promptly to the concerns raised by the Committee in a further submission to Cabinet. The Committee considers that Cabinet funding approval should not be given to the Department to acquire computing facilities until the detailed studies recommended in this report have been completed, and the Department has demonstrated to Cabinet that it has selected the most cost effective means of meeting its information requirements.

In May 1985 the Committee issued its initial guidelines for the content of submissions to the Committee under its standing reference, and invited comments from departments on these. It has to date received no comments. The Committee itself has identified some areas of deficiency and of potential improvement. It now intends, with the benefit of its experience of the four inquiries it has now completed under the reference, to issue revised guidelines which will assist departments to prepare submissions that will meet the Committee's needs and therefore expedite the process of the Committee's inquiry and report. The Committee continues to welcome any comments that interested departments and agencies may wish to make on the guidelines. I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to draw the Senate's attention to part of this report. It is on page 9 under the heading `General Issues'. I believe that what is contained in this section of the report should be part of the Hansard record on this matter. The Committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: General Issues

36. The Committee has concerns about a general presumption in the Department of Community Services' submission that it has a right to an `autonomous' computing capability simply by virtue of its existence as a department. The proliferation of separate departmental systems could lead to increasing effort, cost and frustration in transferring computing equipment and software from one departmental system to another. Such a situation would arise, for example following a decision by Government to reallocate departmental responsibilities. There may also be substantial continuing costs associated with the transfer of computer-based information between departments and agencies with common or related information needs.

37. These costs could be reduced by departments with closely related functions and/or the need to exchange substantial amounts of computer-based information, agreeing to establish a common computing `environment' or computing architecture. There would of course be other important considerations and costs associated with such an initiative including the consequent restriction of choice on open tendering in subsequent computing acquisitions by these departments.

38. The Committee notes that the Department of Community Services has commissioned an Information Sharing Feasibility Study, the results of which are not yet available. The purpose of the study is to determine the viability of sharing common data holdings between DCS and other Commonwealth, State and Local Government and non-Government organisations. The Committee understands that the study commenced with an examination of the program objectives, strategies and data requirements of Victorian Government departments. Compatibility with Commonwealth Government departments appears not to have been accorded a high priority.

The Committee concludes that there may be benefit in departments with related responsibilities and information needs having computing facilities with a common computing `environment' or systems architecture; the Department of Community Services is examining the feasibility of sharing information with other Commonwealth, State and Local Government organisations, but appears to have accorded a higher priority to compatibility with State and Local Government organisations rather than related Commonwealth Government departments and agencies.

The Committee recommends that the Public Service Board, in consultation with the Departments of Finance and Local Government and Administrative Services undertake an examination of the cost effectiveness of establishing a common computing `environment' or systems architecture to enable a high degree of systems compatibility between departments and agencies with closely related responsibilities and information requirements; and future submissions by departments to the Committee for computing capability should take account of the need for arrangements to facilitate systems compatibility with the computer systems of related departments.

We believe that the subject raised under `General Issues' is a matter for important consideration, having in mind that from time to time governments alter ministerial arrangements. Some departments are divided, some are consolidated, and in such arrangements a deal of wastage and cost can be involved. Past executive and administrative decisions have led to some problems in paper work. They have led to considerable wastage in the printing of letterheads and other matters. They were only minor considerations, but when it comes to installation of computer systems one should take account of what could happen when departments are rearranged. For that reason the Committee decided to report on the general issue of establishing compatibility within an environment in which certain organisations and departments have a part. I commend the report, and I thank Senator Guilfoyle for her chairmanship of the sessional committee, and also the staff for their dedication and application in preparing the report, especially those who were seconded to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend this paper to the Senate. World-wide, developing countries are enduring an economic crisis of massive proportions. The people in these countries are suffering from poverty and unemployment and their development programs are suffering setbacks as commodity prices plummet on world markets. Australia is suffering like the rest of the world, but here the cities are insulated from the worst effects. However, many of our country people are facing desperation as they struggle to keep their land and their hope, while their families undergo humiliating poverty in an attempt to meet rising costs with an income a fraction of what is needed to cover these costs. It is time to implement a new world economic order.

SPEECH.PARA: A parallel and associated problem for developed nations is the threat of failure of the world banking system. Developing countries can no longer meet their interest payments on foreign debt. The consequence for lending nations is the imminent collapse of their major banks. Those countries also are desperate for a new world economic order.

The time is ripe, probably for the first time since the end of colonialism, for the developing nations to unite in negotiating new terms of trade and international finance. Peru, Mexico and the Philippines have already made a stand individually and proved the readiness of the banking nations to negotiate. This is all dealt with to some extent in the report on page 8, although it is very much understated.

I welcome the Government's initiative in calling preliminary talks in Cairns between developing countries, to agree on a united approach to the round of multilateral trade negotiations just beginning. However, this is only one aspect of the current breakdown in world trade. We also need to renegotiate the basis for international economic justice. Peru's initiative in tying its loan payments to the prices it receives on international sales of its commodities is an example of what could be a just basis for a new world economy. I look for the Government's initiative for Australia to take the lead in bringing developing and under-developed nations together with the main banking nations and developed countries, to resolve the problems of economic injustice which plague us all.

If hunger, poverty and injustice are ignored, if countries such as Indonesia, the Philippines, Brazil, Chile, Argentina, Mexico, Peru and Australia are pushed over the brink of despair, this may well trigger a new world war of disastrous proportions. The time is ripe to establish a new world economic order, and I believe that the Government should be doing all it can to encourage this.

Within Australia we also have a crisis looming. Our cotton farmers, wheat farmers, sugar farmers, vignerons and orchardists are facing international price cuts as the European Economic Community, the United States of America, and developing countries desperate for foreign exchange in trying to pay their debts, dump surplus stocks of subsidised produce on our traditional markets. This type of dumping is the type of thing that the trade negotiations are trying to get over.

The Government has no plan in place to support our farmers and their families through this crisis. There are no alternative industries which can generate work or alternative opportunities for these farmers. The Government is ignoring the farmers' plight, leaving them to the fate of bankruptcy or at the mercy of their banks. Instead, the Government continues to protect non-exporting foreign-owned manufacturing industries and so continues to tax exporting industries, including farmers. It thus generates very high unemployment and high costs for consumers. I believe that we have a very serious problem on our hands. TALK.START.PARA: —I commend this paper to the Senate. SPEECH.PARA: There have been two applicants for the RCTS licence, one of which was Imparja Television Pty Ltd which has a major input from CAAMA-the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association. This group has been successful in obtaining the licence. However, there is a real problem in this area in that the granting of the licence has been challenged by the other applicant and the Northern Territory Government. Thus we have two companies, one of which is mainly owned by a public broadcasting operation called CAAMA, with some backup from the Federal and State governments, and the other, Television Capricornia, which is mainly made up of commercial television interests with some backing from the Northern Territory Government.

Both applicants were sent away by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in its preliminary hearings because the Tribunal felt that neither qualified for the granting of the licence. The Tribunal had serious reservations about the financial backing of Imparja because the Federal Government was very lax in coming up with the type of support that was necessary for such an organisation. It also had very grave doubts about the adequacy of the service proposed by Television Capricornia. Further hearings were scheduled in March in Alice Springs. At the time this happened I was able to ask the Government a number of questions, some without notice and some on notice. I was trying to move the Government into allocating some money to the Imparja group if it were successful. Indeed, I believe that it was because of those questions I submitted that Imparja eventually got a guarantee of $2.5m and I am very proud that this occurred. However, after that there was an appeal against the Tribunal's decision and that appeal is now being heard.

I really believe that Imparja has an excellent record in this area. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: 4.34)-I rise to speak briefly on the fourth report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on remote commercial television services. This report is about the fourth licence to be issued for remote commercial television service broadcasting. Whereas in the previous three cases there has been little or no dispute about the award of the licence, on this occasion there has been a very significant dispute. It gives me no great pleasure to say that a large amount of that dispute goes not to the question of the viability of the successful tenderer, Imparja Television Pty Ltd, but goes very directly to questions which turn upon the fact that the station is primarily Aboriginal in terms of its philosophy and ownership. This is not a broadcasting issue; it is a racial issue. No one can stand back from that judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, in deciding to award a broadcasting licence, takes account of seven criteria. These criteria are: Whether the applicant has a good association and involvement with the region; whether the applicant is well informed about the needs of the region; whether the applicant's programming proposals are adequate; whether it proposes to deliver an adequate and comprehensive service and whether it has financial capabilities; whether it has technical capabilities and whether it has management capabilities. In each of these seven areas Imparja was pitted against Television Cap- ricornia Pty Ltd, the other bidder for the licence. Imparja was locally based, being associated with broadcasting station 8KIN, Alice Springs, and with the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association, known as CAAMA. Television Capricornia has its links with channel 8, TTV Darwin.

Of the seven criteria it was found that, in terms of technical and management capability, both applicants were equal; in terms of financial capability, Television Capricornia was better placed; but in terms of association and involvement in the region, information about the region, programming proposals and the adequacy and comprehensiveness of proposed services, Imparja was the better qualified. If one wishes to take a very crude score, of the seven points, Capricornia scored one, Imparja scored four and the other two were regarded as equal. On this basis Imparja was awarded the broadcast licence.

TALK.START.PARA: —On merit.

—As Senator Peter Baume says, it was awarded on merit. There is no doubt about that. It is certainly true that there are some questions about Imparja's financial structure. It is receiving $1.8m from the Aboriginal Development Commission and $2.5m from the Australian Bicentennial Authority under somewhat strange circumstances, let it be conceded. Nevertheless, despite this very large amount of financial involvement being provided out of the public purse-as indeed those two grants are-in all respects Imparja appears to be the better qualified of the two applicants. It is certainly true that it proposes to do some broadcasting in Aboriginal community languages. I welcome that rather than criticise it. Imparja, in its programming proposals which it put to the Tribunal, indicated that this would be a fairly small part of its broadcasting-only a couple of hours a week. The issues in this are well summarised in an editorial in the Australian Financial Review of 1 September 1986 headed `A television issue in black and white'. I seek leave to have that editorial incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The editorial read as follows-

The howls of dismay from rival commercial interests and the Northern Territory Government over the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's decision to grant Australia's fourth and final remote commercial television service licence to an Aboriginal body are hardly surprising but are misguided.

The licence entails responsibility for providing a commercial television service, as well as some radio broadcasting, to an area extending from the Gove Peninsula in the most northerly part of the Northern Territory, to Kangaroo Island, off South Australia.

In terms of area, this is about 30 per cent of Australia's total land expanse. The service will not include major population centres such as Darwin or Adelaide. Its nearest approach to an ``urban'' population will be Alice Springs. The total population to be served is about 120,000.
Within the area to be served it is estimated that about 27 per cent of the population is Aboriginal.
The license (valid for seven years in the first instance) has been awarded to Imparja Television Pty Ltd, of which the major shareholder is the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association.
CAAMA has operated a multi-dialect broadcasting service (including video) for the past two years and is therefore not completely new to the broadcast field.

The predictable reaction of both the Northern Territory Government and the rival applicant for the licence, Darwin's NTD-8 Television Capricornia, was that the decision had been influenced by ``social engineering'' considerations and by an element of reverse discrimination in favour of Aborigines.

In a broad sense there is probably some truth to this. But ``social engineering'' has not yet become an accepted pejorative term, and there is surely a strong case to be made in specific instances for some positive discrimination favouring our Aboriginal population.

Indeed, in political entities such as the Northern Territory where there is powerful evidence that a small and aberrant political structure leads to severe anti-black discrimination, or even oppression of Aborigines, countervailing policies could be seen as an inescapable duty of national government.
Technology, culture and financial reality all combine in this instance to support a case for an Aboriginal licensee.

The ABT, to its credit, has been willing to take a gamble on an innovative move which is certainly not assured of success (even more certainly, no licence to print money) but which seems to have a reasonable chance.
Satellite technology is what has made it possible to consider remote area television.

For thousands of people who have had no television or local radio, no daily mail deliveries and very little contact with the rest of the country, let alone the outside world, there is now the prospect of access not only to television and radio but also associated telecommunications services such as facsimile and telephone.
The very nature of outback society suggests that most of these benefits will flow primarily to the white population.
But the real key to the ABT's decision lies in two other factors.
First, the issue of the cultural destruction of the Aboriginal-already well advanced by indiscriminate and undiscriminating contact with European civilisation.

The introduction of conventional commercial television, with its general emphasis on superficially projected Western values such as greed, violence and materialism can hardly in itself be expected to do much to help Aboriginal societies come to terms with white Australia.
Even white Australians are constantly expressing their concern about the submergence or subversion of their own culture by imported television material.
Aboriginal programming in local dialects can provide some kind of counterbalance to a flood of conventional television fare although it will be confined to about three hours a week.

Second, the best safeguard of the interests of non-Aboriginal viewers is quite simply the fact that this is a commercial licence-even though it seems that up to $5 million of public money will be required (and has been committed) to get the project off the ground.
The programming will have to be as conscious of ratings as that of any city television station, particularly among the more affluent section of its viewership.

This clash of interests will provide some interesting days at Imparja TV and it will only work effectively if it is made apparent quite sternly from the beginning that the Federal Government is not looking to any more turtle farms or other examples of socio-economic engin- eering gone wrong.
On the whole, in the present economic climate, it seems unlikely that any Government money other than that already committed to get the project started will be forthcoming.
But the question does raise another, closely related issue.

There is a certain inconsistency about the Government's decision to fund what is in effect a new ethnic broadcasting service at the very time that it has determined (at some political cost) that its greatest experiment in this field, the SBS, is no longer affordable and must be merged with the ABC.

Of course, the difference between the SBS and the Imparja television licence is that one was wholly funded by the taxpayer and the other is supposed to pay its own way through advertising and other telecommunications revenue.
Why, then, was the SBS not given the alternative of funding itself through advertising revenue (with the same kind of statutory ethnic responsibilities applying to Imparja)?

A commercial SBS network would have been an excellent dry run for the day when the ABC will have to accept advertising (which cannot be far distant now) and would have given that network an opportunity to pursue the potentialities denied it by bureaucratic interference.
The immigrant ethnic communities have every justification for being upset by the Government's lofty, unimaginative tactics towards SBS.
It can only be hoped that the Aboriginal ethnic community will not be similarly disappointed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I conclude by saying that although this is a risky business and although the Tribunal has embarked on a bold and certainly potentially risky decision in awarding this licence to Imparja, I believe that Imparja was the better qualified of the two applicants. It went through all the necessary procedures, the tender was looked at and the licence was fairly awarded. I hope that Imparja will make a great success of this project and that a new dimension will be added to broadcasting in Australia. The normal range of Australian Broadcasting Corporation, commercial, ethnic, public and CB broadcasting is now complemented with Aboriginal broadcasting. I think that that can only enrich the whole Australian community.

The public sector, however, suffered enormous underwriting losses, even more than the private sector. Compulsory third party motor vehicle insurance contributed mainly to this loss, because of the lack of coverage and the failure of our various programs to mitigate injury in car accidents. Overall, the profitability of private insurers continued to improve while that of the public insurers continued to deteriorate. This puts us at a disadvantage compared with overseas companies which currently may sell insurance directly in Australia. This insur- ance is not guaranteed by the Insurance Commissioner. It is extremely important that we should ensure that overseas insurers are not given an overall advantage.

The fire service levy should be removed. More and more multinational companies are insuring overseas in order to avoid these costs and the local insurance market is being hit. This is one of the reasons why we have such a large invisibles debt. Governments, both Federal and State, are responsible for this particular matter. It would help to make Australian insurers competitive in world market terms if the fire service levy were removed or collected in another way. I believe that it should be collected directly from overseas insurers as well. Stamp duty is another problem for local insurers. I believe that this matter should be looked at by the State people.

In this report the Commissioner has again raised the problem of standards and the determination of real viability in the local insurance industry. The Commissioner details the areas where suitable accounting standards are needed and suggests that his Office undertake a process of reform through consultation with the industry. I commend this particular action to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I believe that we should take a lot more notice of insurance in trade and industry and should introduce a reinsurance market in Australia. I have a Bill available for this in the Senate if either the Government or the Opposition wish to pick it up.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are four small points I wish to make with respect to the Qantas Airways Ltd annual report 1985-86. The points are small in the sense of the number of words I intend to use, but I believe that they will be substantial in their content. The first two points relate to Qantas's refusal to show the anti-drug film prepared by the Department of Foreign Affairs and, secondly, its very cavalier attitude to the carrying of health warnings on the packets of cigarettes sold on the airline. Those two points can be grouped under the subject heading of corporate morality. Qantas's activities with respect to both of those points show that it has a corporate morality which is not consistent with it calling itself the spirit of Australia. The Government should be doing everything it can to pressure Qantas to lift its game in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: The anti-drug film, which I have seen, is an excellent film. It serves as a warning to all Australians travelling overseas of the dangers not only against getting involved in drugs but also in relation to luggage. For example, it warns people of the trouble they can get into if they carry packages for friends through airports. It is a very good film which is articulately presented and one that is being shown by Cathay-Pacific, which deserves to be congratulated for showing the film.

The morality of Qantas can be highlighted easily by pointing out that on the one hand it says that the film is unsuitable to show on international flights because it will frighten passengers, but on the other hand it says that if it were given $80,000 or $90,000 a year the film might be suitable. Inconsistent claims have been made about the involvement of Qantas in the production of the film. The Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) who in this chamber represents the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) told this chamber that Qantas was involved, or at the very least consulted, throughout the production of the film, yet Qantas says that because the Government put the film to it on a take it or leave it basis, it now has to produce its own film. These are inconsistent reports and I intend to pursue those matters. None of these matters is mentioned on page 12 of the report under the heading `Community Relations', nor has Qantas identified exactly how much it spends on community relations. I believe that Qantas should be spending more money to get its act together with respect to its refusal to show this film and the non-placement of health warnings on cigarette packets carried on the airline.

Qantas was pursued in this regard by Senator Peter Baume at the hearings of Estimates Committee F. I will make only a few comments about this matter because he may wish to make some comments himself. The basic answer that came from Qantas was: `We do not show health warnings because we do not have to'. To my way of thinking, that is a totally inadequate answer. Lots of us do things that we do not have to do because we perceive them to be the appropriate things to do. Qantas was asked also whether it had done a contra deal with Philip Morris Ltd to produce carry bags for people to put the duty free goods in that they buy on Qantas aircraft. Qantas said that it had done a contra deal with Philip Morris and people from Philip Morris get travel up to the cost of the bags produced. One wonders why Qantas has not done a contra deal with some other body such as the Australian Tourist Commission, or the Buy Australia campaign. One does not need to be bright or imaginative to think of a wide range of bodies other than Philip Morris with which Qantas could have done a contra deal.

The other point to which I refer is the inability of Qantas to carry international passengers on domestic sectors. I believe that something should be done about that. The Chairman of Qantas has referred to that matter in his report. I believe that is a very sensible request which the Government should take up. The final point relates to the nine directors of Qantas, five of whom have been appointed since the election of this Government. All of the directors, including the five appointed by this Government, are male. I am not sure whether that is a reflection on the needs of Qantas or the sincerity with which this Government pursues its policy of placing women on boards, but I refer that matter to the Government to be looked at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to follow the remarks made by my colleague Senator Vanstone, though I will not rehearse them. It is worth pointing out to the Senate that Senator Gietzelt, the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation in this place, did tell us a couple of days ago that following the pressure applied by Senate Estimates Committee F, of which Senator Vanstone is a member, Qantas Airways Ltd has decided to change the cigarette packets it will sell once current stocks are sold. So the Estimates Committee has achieved something.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to use this occasion to refer to the sequence of events that surrounded the questioning itself-the process of questioning and the unsatisfactory way in which the Department of Aviation has behaved in response to questions put to it by the Estimates Committee. First, advance notice was given to the Department of Aviation that some questions were to be put concerning Qantas Airways. No officers from Qantas were present at the examination of the estimates, and this was referred to by the Estimates Committee in its report when it said that the questions were not properly addressed at the hearing as no representative of Qantas was in attendance. I put it on the record that the attendance of an officer from Qantas had been requested. A letter subsequently received from the Chairman of Qantas indicates that this problem will not arise again. Secondly, questions asked at the Estimates Committee relating to the sale of cigarettes had to be taken on notice. Eventually a response was obtained from the Department of Aviation after the time properly allowed for the Department to answer, and that occurred only after Senate Estimates Committee F had gone back to the Department asking where its responses were. An answer to one of my questions was not received, a Mr Moffatt for the Department saying:

. . . the response to Senator Baume's questions concerning Qantas . . . is not attached. Qantas is involved in investigating questions of law with the Department of Health. A response will be forwarded as soon as it becomes available.

Not unnaturally as a result of this, Estimates Committee F had some rather harsh things to say about Qantas Airways, and in a report put before the Senate it took Qantas to task. A letter was written subsequently to the Chairman of Qantas asking for answers to the questions forthwith. It now transpires that Qantas had provided the answers requested well in advance of the answers being received by the Senate from the Department of Aviation. It appears that the answers had gone to the Department of Aviation and it was the Department, not Qantas, which was seeking legal advice, and that the Department of Aviation in its letter to the Estimates Committee of 15 October had misled the Estimates Committee and misled the Senate when it suggested that a response had not been received from Qantas Airways Ltd. A letter was subsequently received from the Department of Aviation saying that the answer it gave was not completely correct. It certainly was not completely correct.

We have here one more example of a second rate department attempting to deal other than completely openly and honestly with a Senate Estimates committee in response to what are really perfectly innocuous questions-questions of fact which go to matters within the Department's administrative responsibility. It is simply not good enough that it did not have officers there to answer the questions when it was given advance notice. It is not good enough that, having taken the questions on notice, it did not provide answers within the time allowed. It is not good enough that, when it did respond to the Committee, it did not tell the truth and in fact attempted to suggest to the Committee, in the response signed by J. F. Moffatt for the First Assistant Secretary of the Resources Division, that no answers had been received, and it was only when Qantas itself was taken to task and when Qantas itself wrote to the Committee saying that answers had been provided that the Department of Aviation advised that in fact the answers it had given to the Estimates Committee had not been completely correct.

I suggest to the Department of Aviation that we are far from satisfied. If this is the degree of efficiency which the Department exercises in answering simple questions from Senate Estimates committees, one wonders how it can fulfil its other tasks which may require rather more subtlety in administration or rather more responsibility in management, and I for one will be watching very closely what the Department of Aviation does in its next and future appearances before Senate Estimates committees.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today we debated various matters relating to industrial relations and the steel industry. In that debate a report of the Steel Industry Authority was referred to particularly by me to demonstrate the concerns being expressed about the future of the steel industry. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, responded that I was clutching at straws, that I was objecting to the seven steps forward and one step back that he claims to have taken place in this industry. I asked him repeatedly by way of interjection whether he was prepared to accept or reject the findings of the Steel Industry Authority. Of course he selectively chose not to respond to those interjections-as is his right.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this is an important question that this Government had better face up to. Does it believe in this report signed by Mr Dolan, the former President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, or does it not? Will it do something about it, or will it rest on tawdry comparisons with the level of industrial unrest that existed back in the 1970's and early 1980's before the steel industry plan, which involves the expenditure of public moneys, was introduced in order to save the steel industry and save jobs and which carries with it an obligation on the unions involved to stick by what was then called an accord in this industry, imposed on it by the Government as a condition of this public funding. The report says, quite clearly, that this accord has been breached. It says:
The Authority is concerned that the success of the Plan might be jeopardised by single groups pursuing individual interests against the greater good of the industry.
That is not me talking; that is the report. It states:
. . . the Authority sought the intervention of the ACTU and drew the attention of the unions concerned to their obligations under the Steel Industry Plan.
That is not me talking; it is the report. The report noted:
In the Accord between BHP and the unions it was agreed that both parties-

of course that accord was produced as a result of the Government requiring it as a result of its contribution of large amounts of public moneys, $21m in bounties this year, as well as tariffs and other protective devices-
would comply with established dispute settlement procedures to reduce the incidence of disruption leading to the loss of wages and production.
The report concludes:
There is strong evidence to suggest that this part of the Accord had not been followed over the last six months of the year, particularly at Port Kembla.

The Minister did not seem to care about that; he did not want to respond to it. He did not want to say whether or not he was concerned about the report; all he was concerned with doing was making cheap political points. One knows darned well that whenever the name Patrick Partners is introduced into a debate by a Government senator the Opposition has scored a telling point in terms of fact and Government senators have no response other than personal abuse. That is exactly what happened again today. We received no response from the Minister to this statement on work and management practices in the report:
In this regard there appears to be a direct correlation between the increase in man hours lost and the more difficult nature of the work and management practices being addressed.

If this pattern of industrial disputation continues, it does not augur well for the success of the industry over the remainder of the Plan and, consequently, for the longer-term security of employment.

This is the report speaking; it is not me, as the Minister said, allegedly clutching at straws. This is a major report of major concern. The Minister has no concern or involvement in doing anything about it. He simply made cheap political points. The report says:
. . . if action is not taken to eliminate them-
that is, these work and management practices-
the industry could be overtaken by competitive pressures and-enforced retrenchments may well result.
That is the report speaking. The report also says:
. . . there was an alarming increase of man hours lost through industrial disputes leading to a loss of production and wages . . . at Port Kembla . . .

In general, this report is a damning indictment of the Government's inability to control the union movement and to maintain the increases in productivity that this plan was bringing about which are now being sabotaged by continual industrial unrest. The report continues:
The Authority strongly urges the parties to abide by their commitments and to reverse this trend-
of industrial unrest-
over the remaining life of the Plan.
Otherwise, as it properly notes, overall, the future of this industry is in jeopardy.
