TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to the Senate and wish to draw attention to specific concerns expressed in the report surrounding the Government's introduction of a $250 so-called administrative charge which, in all senses, is actually a fee on tertiary students. The Commission has expressed some concerns. While the report notes that certain groups are to be exempted, and they are listed, it expresses concern about a considerable group of people who will find themselves just beyond the means test limit of eligibility for the Austudy allowance. Very often that group finds itself between a rock and a hard place in our society. It is suggested that, because of the introduction of this fee, access to education will be limited for quite a considerable group of people who fall into that category.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of some concern that the report notes that there will be new demands, as a result of this imposition, on the special assistance for students scheme. It notes that by 1987, $11m will have been made available to institutions. The report states:
It is the Commission's intention that these funds be used by institutions to help students whose enrolments may be in jeopardy because of the administration charge.

I think this smacks rather of robbing Peter to pay Paul. The Commission calls quite strongly for monitoring of the effect of the imposition of this $250 fee and says that it will be fairly clear early next year what the impact is but that the monitoring must continue beyond the beginning of next year to ensure that any anomalies and undesirable outcomes are identified and corrective measures are taken. It is already possible to determine some considerable anomalies. If the Opposition, although expressing its outrage about the imposition of this fee, votes for the legislation in this House, as it has done in the other place, we will have this fee. We suggest that anomalies are already identifiable. The fact that part time students should be paying $250 just the same as full time students is certainly inequitable if not anomalous, as is the fact that single subject and external students will be doing the same.

Outrage has been expressed both in the Parliament and outside. I draw attention to an article in today's Adelaide Advertiser which states that the legislation introducing the fee has been passed-which, of course, is inaccurate; it has not passed the Senate yet-and that the Opposition spokesperson on education expressed this outrage and identified external and part time students as possible victims. We suggest that if the Opposition cannot bring itself to join us in opposing the legislation to ensure that this fee is not introduced, the very least that it could do is support the Australian Democrats' amendment to remove those anomalies before they come into play. The Commission does say in its report that the adequacy of that $11m special assistance student payment next year will be really at risk because of the very anomalies which are identifiable now and which would be addressed in this chamber when the legislation comes before us.

It is interesting that one of the points made also by the Opposition spokesperson is that students can expect a massive rise in the charge in future years. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Economic Planning Advisory Council's role is to act as a vehicle for community participation in the development of government economic policy, I accept the challenge that that mechanism provides, together with the occasion of the presentation of this annual report to the Senate. The Council, as we know, is briefed on current economic conditions and outlook by the Treasurer, Paul Keating, at each meeting and Council members also receive comprehensive briefings on the labour market and on trends in prices and incomes by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). Despite the Government's close liaison with the Council and subsequent advice from a body specialising in the economic affairs of the nation, I believe that the Government has been tardy to act or it has failed to act on information tendered by its advisory body, or it may be that it has mishandled the implementation of its economic policies.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the 1985-86 annual report, Council members have expressed concern that without sustained high rates of economic growth, unemployment will remain a serious problem for some considerable time. If we look at the current economic situation, we see a climate of high inflation, rising interest rates and climbing unemployment. On 3 September 1986 an article in the Australian newspaper stated:
. . . rising unemployment is now unavoidable, as the rapid increase in interest rates has virtually destroyed the strategy of the August Budget and is squeezing business.
We read in today's Press how mounting debt is causing massive problems to the viability of many companies operating in this country.

The balance of payments has become a focal point of the Council as it is seen as a major constraint on economic growth. The Director of EPAC stated in the report that Australia's economic growth performance could be improved by a number of factors, including managing the economy in such a way as to maintain an optimal level of capacity utilisation and expanding productive performance. So a guide is given. It is not really known whether the Government has been taking heed of this advice, but it certainly does not appear at this stage to be taking steps to implement policies which will achieve the objectives outlined by the Council.

At this point I question the wholly independent nature of the Economic Planning Advisory Council. The report states that one of the functions of EPAC is to act as a major forum for discussion between government bodies and representatives of the community on economic conditions and appropriate policies for Commonwealth governments to adopt. However, if one looks at the membership of this Council, one sees on page 1 of the report that there are three high-ranking government representatives-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Furthermore, there are four other government representatives, mostly from State Labor governments and, in addition, four union delegates. So EPAC is designed to be representative of the community but it is clear that, instead, it is representative of narrow, factional interests.

The Council gives little consideration to outside submissions and it is, therefore, limited in its ability to function as a forum for community participation. In addition, the Council is subject to a number of internal constraints. The Chairman of the Council is the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the Deputy Chairman is the Treasurer, Paul Keating. So the Chairman determines the general view of EPAC and seeks responses from the Council on particular issues. In most instances the Government presents the submissions for discussion by the group, and only those areas on which the Council has consensus are released as reports. There is another big constraint on its credibility. A further constraint is the Government's insistence that policy objectives are consistently framed in terms of the conditions of the accord. It is the accord, therefore, that dictates the Government's policy directions. Given that the aim of EPAC is to advise the Government on feasible and desirable targets for the Australian economy, I am by no means convinced that the Council is either properly equipped or sufficiently independent to function in its intended role. At this point it is apparent, I think, that EPAC is no more than a tool with which the Government can mobilise consent for its policies. I believe it is therefore merely a token gesture. Its other failing is that it is prone to coming to dramatic conclusions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the Senate takes note of this annual report of the Economic Planning Advisory Council because I think it comes at a very opportune time. At the same time as this annual report is being released EPAC has released a critical analysis of the present balance of trade situation. It is interesting to reflect that one of the functions of EPAC, according to its annual report, is:

SPEECH.PARA: Undertaking professionally independent and objective economic research and analysis, to assist the Council and the broader community in arriving at judgments on economic and policy issues.
It also states:
Media coverage of the Council Papers series stimulated considerable public interest and debate.

I will mention the composition of this Council in a moment. This Council has the ability to talk up the economy and to bear down on the economy. I hope some of the eminent persons on that Council are not just being used as political tools. I think we should look again at its composition, to which Senator Watson has already referred. There are three Australian Labor Party members of the Federal Parliament, who are all ex-trade union representatives, Mr Simon Crean and three other trade union representatives. That makes a total of seven out of the 18 members of the Advisory Council from the trade union movement. Throw in as well two Labor Premiers, to whom Senator Watson has already referred, and we have what I would probably call a hung council. I wonder how independent this Advisory Council really is. It is really the Labor Government being advised by the trade union movement and getting credibility for some of the things with which the Planning Advisory Council comes down.

This Advisory Council has cost the taxpayer $2.429m, according to page 12 of its annual report. I wonder whether the taxpayers in the community are getting out of it the value that they would like. The outlook paper which was published recently-I could quote from it as well-gives very grim warnings to the Government about what it should be doing. I make the point that it is advising itself on its own advice. It is probably quite embarrassing to think that while the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was away trying to talk up the economy a report was published which says:
. . . the necessary conditions for the desired turn- around in the trade and debt position include:
Reasonable stability in the terms of trade.
No further deterioration in real interest rates.
A sustained switch in demand from foreign goods to Australian products.
An increase in the domestic savings rate.
Appropriate supply responses from industry . . .

That is what EPAC is advising the Government to do. I ask: Is the Government taking any notice of its own advisers, even though it is advising itself? The fact that this grim picture has been painted and that we will have this terrible outlook for 1990 has fallen on deaf ears as far as the Government is concerned. I think we must ask ourselves: What sort of advice is EPAC giving to the Government? Is the taxpayer really getting value for his money from this Advisory Council?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This latest annual report of the Economic Planning Advisory Council says on page 5:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Council members have expressed concern that without sustained high rates of economic growth, unemployment will remain a serious problem for some considerable time.

I draw the Senate's attention to that sentence simply because economic growth is, of course, collapsing under the Government's present economic policies. The Budget forecast that domestic economic growth would be reduced to about 0.5 per cent has now apparently been revised in private talks overseas by Dr Barry Hughes, the economic adviser to the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to no growth whatsoever in the internal economy. Yet the Treasurer is quite content to continue maintaining this quaint fiction that there will be something like a 2 1/4 per cent growth in gross domestic product over the financial year, and that will arise totally, he says, from the net external balance.

It is extraordinary that, having identified the problem, the Economic Planning Advisory Council is now being totally ignored by the Government. That might explain why the Government is running it down so significantly. We recall that in the past, when EPAC was providing information with which the Government did not agree, that information was censored and EPAC was then prevented from undertaking projections relating to the consequences of the movement of various variables in the economy-for example, wage rises and so on-because particular members of EPAC, and the ones I have in mind were the trade union representatives, objected so strongly and, as usual, the Government acquiesced. Another point that the EPAC annual report makes is:
. . . more recently the balance of payments has emerged as a major constraint on economic growth and has been a focus of attention of Council.
That is particularly interesting, as is its next point:
. . . employment outlook over the medium term is an important issue for further EPAC work and will be a major research theme in 1986-87.

That is in line with the first quote I read about Council members expressing concern about unemployment. It is quite clear that, as economic growth will not be sustained, unemployment will rise. In that context, it is educational to read what Mr Keating had to say on Monday, as reported in the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday of this week:
. . . an analysis of the balance of payments by the Economic Planning Advisory Council accorded with everything that the Government had said.
He continued:
Basically the rise in our external indebtedness comes firstly from a shift away from equity to debt in the 1970s.

While it is all very well for EPAC to be telling the facts, as it sees them, of the economy to the Treasurer, it is extraordinary that the Treasurer would then so distort these facts and so misrepresent what EPAC is telling him that he can come out with this kind of arrant nonsense. His attempt to mislead the Australian people is clear from this statement:
. . . the rise in our external indebtedness comes firstly from a shift away from equity to debt in the 1970s.

That impression is as to significance rather than to time. Let us recall that so far under the Hawke Government the net indebtedness of Australia has trebled. When it came to office in 1983 that debt was about $23 billion; by March it was $62.2 billion and rising; and it is expected to reach something like $85 billion by the end of the year. This nonsensical sort of response by the Treasurer particularly in the face of the latest report, which Senator Brownhill referred to, is a matter of serious consequence to us. The report from EPAC basically underlined that Australians must accept continued high unemployment, tough wage restraint and a string of tough Budgets just to stabilise the soaring foreign debt. It is extraordinary that in the circumstances of EPAC's annual report, which warns of these disturbing things-the latest report on the economy-Mr Keating can continue to mislead this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the Economic Planning Advisory Council. I wish to support some of the things that have been said by the Opposition about this. I basically see EPAC as being a `Mirror, mirror on the wall, who is the fairest of them all' type of exercise. It is not answering in the right way these days, so it is being cut back and punished. That is the picture that we have got.

SPEECH.PARA: EPAC was established in a flourish of enthusiasm after the National Economic Summit in 1983. The report states:
In essence, the Council's role will be to act as a vehicle for community participation in the development of Government economic policy.
Why should the Government seek to cut back EPAC at this crucial stage in Australia's economic adversity unless it is a `Mirror, mirror on the wall' type of activity? The report continues:

The Treasurer made it clear, however, that EPAC's functions extended beyond communication and participation in policy formulation, to include the development of new knowledge on economic policies and economic prospects.
Surely we need new ideas and better understanding when old measures have lead us, in fact, to the current disastrous economic state we are in? The report continues:

An important feature of EPAC referred to by the Treasurer in his Second Reading Speech is its independence. Provision has been made for the council to provide its advice `freely and without unwarranted influence'. While EPAC is required to consult with the Commonwealth Government in deciding which matters it should consider, it is not bound by the Government's views.

As Senator Brownhill has said, although there are nine members on the Council who have come from the Commonwealth or State Labor governments or the trade unions, according to the legislation the Commonwealth members on EPAC are not allowed to vote. The representative nature of the Council ensures two way communications with major community groups affected directly by economic decisions. The proposal to cut back funding to EPAC must be considered together with the whole of the Government's current policy in this area. We have seen a complete turn about in terms of the Government's provision of information to the community. It has completely abandoned its lip service to community participation in decision making and it is closing down or effectively castrating all the bodies which provide an interface between the Government and the people. It has actually done this in the area of the Advisory Council for Inter-government Relations where local government has, in fact, lost faith in Federal consultation; it has done it in the case of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs and the multicultural community has lost faith in that area; and it has done it in Canberra with the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, and now EPAC has been halved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut it out. You did it. You are responsible for it.

—Not at all. The Canberrans have lost faith in the Government because it has not fulfilled its promise of bringing on that so-called self-government legislation for debate. EPAC has been halved because it was telling the Government things that the Government did not want to hear. That is really a problem. We have a Government that will not listen and it is getting more and more into difficulty. The more it gets into difficulty the more it plugs its ears, closes its eyes and ignores the mirror on the wall that is actually telling it the truth.
—Order! The time allowed for consideration of Government papers has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) prepare and bring in a Bill for an Act for the purpose of ensuring that Australian suppliers are given maximum opportunity to compete for Commonwealth contacts for the supply of goods and services, that authorities entering into contracts on behalf of the Commonwealth give proper consideration to Australian suppliers, and that such contracts are awarded to Australian suppliers unless there are cogent reasons for awarding them to non-Australian suppliers, in accordance with the following outline:
PROPOSED COMMONWEALTH CONTRACTS (AUSTRALIAN SUPPLIERS) BILL 1986
Outline of Provisions

1. Purpose of Bill: The purpose of the Bill is to ensure that Australian suppliers are given maximum opportunity to compete for Commonwealth contracts for the supply of goods and services, that authorities entering into contracts on behalf of the Commonwealth give proper consideration to Australian suppliers, and that such contracts are awarded to Australian suppliers unless there are cogent reasons for awarding them to non-Australian suppliers.

2. Application of Bill: The Bill is to apply to all Commonwealth authorities, that is, Commonwealth Departments of State, Parliamentary Departments, statutory authorities and companies owned or controlled by the Commonwealth.

3. General requirement: The Bill is to impose upon Commonwealth authorities a general requirement to ensure that Australian suppliers are given maximum opportunity to compete for Commonwealth contracts, that proper consideration is given to Australian suppliers, and that contracts are awarded to Australian suppliers unless there are cogent reasons for awarding particular contracts to non-Australian suppliers.
4. Australian suppliers: The Bill is to define an Australian supplier in accordance with the following criteria-
(a) for persons other than companies, the persons are to be residents of Australia; and
(b) for companies:
(i) a prescribed percentage of the shareholders is to consist of Australian companies or residents of Australia, or
(ii) a prescribed percentage of the goods to be supplied is to be manufactured in Australia, and
(iii) a prescribed percentage of the profits of the company have been invested in Australia.

5. List of Australian suppliers: The Department of Finance is to compile and maintain a list of Australian suppliers, and collect information to assist Commonwealth authorities to determine whether persons and companies are Australian suppliers.

6. Tenders and quotations: Where the value of contracts is more than a prescribed amount, tenders are to be invited and the invitations to tender are to be directed to the attention of known Australian suppliers. Where the value of contracts is less than that prescribed amount but more than a lower prescribed amount, quotations are to be sought from known suppliers. Exemptions from these requirements may be granted by the Minister for Finance in cases of urgency or exceptional circumstances, and any exemptions are to be laid before both Houses of the Parliament. In submitting tenders or quotations suppliers are to indicate whether they are Australian suppliers, and penalties are to be provided for any false statement.
7. Award of contracts: The award of contracts and the terms of contracts are to be published, together with a statement indicating whether the suppliers are Australian suppliers.

8. Statement of reasons: Where a contract is awarded to a person other than an Australian supplier, the publication referred to in paragraph 7 is to be accompanied by a statement of reasons for the award of the contract to a non-Australian supplier. This statement is to be laid before each House of the Parliament and forwarded to any Australian suppliers who tendered or quoted for the contract. Those suppliers are to be furnished with additional information relating to the reasons for their failure to gain the contract, and any further information relating thereto which they request.

9. Advance notice of contracts: Commonwealth authorities are to give advance notice of invitations to tender for contracts with a value above a prescribed amount, indicating the technology requirements involved in the contracts.

As honourable senators are doubtless aware, centralised purchasing by the Commonwealth has enabled the Commonwealth to achieve considerable price concessions through bulk purchasing and has, in fact, saved a great deal of money to the taxpayer. However, it has resulted in centralised purchasing from overseas a lot easier. Centralised purchasing has allowed strict purchasing guidelines to be established, tighter control procedures to be followed, and tighter procedures for quality and price control. Another outcome has been the high level of accountability of the Australian Public Service in this area.

However, the consequential buying clout which the Commonwealth has achieved has been a two-edged sword. It has left the Commonwealth with an enormous responsibility to act wisely and not to the disadvantage of the Australian people. A major problem is that even though a Bill in 1980 was put before the Parliament-it was called the Procurement of Goods, Works and Services Bill; it was renamed in this Parliament the Preference to Australian Goods (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill-and passed through both Houses, that particular legislation has never been proclaimed. The legislation that was put forward in 1980 has been lying about and nothing has been done about it. This does not augur very well for the types of proposals that I am putting forward now.

Hopefully, we are in a very different situation now. We are in a situation where Mr Hawke is appearing on television and in the media, saying to private industry and to the people of Australia that they should buy Australian. Yet we have a Public Service which is not necessarily buying Australian. We have enormous buying power in the Department of Defence, in telecommunications and, in fact, over the whole of the Public Service. They are buying at the cheapest price rather than following the guidelines which would make it much more comfortable for them to buy Australian. One of the reasons for this is the cultural cringe which we have about Australian goods. We believe somehow that something which comes from overseas must be better, particularly technology. I appeal to two people within the Australian community not to give in to this cringe, particularly public servants. I think we should make it easier for public servants not to give in. We should make it more difficult for them to buy foreign goods. The proposals of this Bill are aimed at making the tendering process easier for Australian companies and slightly more difficult or painstaking for the public servants when they wish to do something else than buy Australia. We want to make it the norm for the buying process to buy Australian.

Firstly, the proposed Commonwealth Contracts (Australian Suppliers) Bill 1986 provides the ability for a list of Australian suppliers to be kept. It provides for a tender process to be used for larger contracts but that the tender process may be by-passed and a quotation system on the local market introduced for smaller purchases. This will make it easier for small business in Australia to tender for government contracts and not to be totally daunted by the fact that the Commonwealth's requirements may represent a very large component of their output. Contracts awarded on the basis of a tender or a quotation must be published with a statement to indicate which of the suppliers are Australian. It is extremely important for people who are overseeing the process of purchasing to be able to see what contracts go overseas and what the actual cost in foreign currency is for that export of jobs.

Where contracts go to overseas suppliers, publication must include a statement of the reason that the contract has been allotted to an overseas company. That is a very important deterrent for people in the Public Service who might take the view that, as the biggest firm in the world is producing something, it must be the best product, instead of taking the trouble to look at a local Australian alternative. It is extremely important that we have this type of accessibility to the reasons why contracts go overseas, so that we can correct it at source.

Part of this process is that in the Bill outline we also provide for Australian suppliers to be given at least a year's notice of any large contracts coming up in an area. Large contracts are to be defined within the Bill. These are the main provisions; they are very simple. They in no way force the public servants to buy Australian. They do not infringe any of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade arrangements. What they do is to make it very uncomfortable for people to buy overseas for the wrong reasons. Many wrong reasons are used currently for buying overseas. Indeed, it is not necessarily in the best interests of Australian industry that the Commonwealth buys the cheapest goods available, especially if those cheapest goods are imported.

If the Commonwealth is the largest customer of an Australian supplier, the loss of a regular Commonwealth contract could in fact force that supplier out of business. So we also need an ability for the local contractor to have some degree of continuity for his product in terms of Commonwealth contracts. On the other hand, a supplier may not bid for Commonwealth contracts because for him to supply the required volume may require an enormous investment in new equipment. A guarantee of continuing supply must be necessary in order to enable the supplier to tender without leaving himself exposed to overall loss of the contract.

It is a disadvantage to Australian suppliers to deal with a centralised Commonwealth purchasing operation. It gives cartel powers to the Government since the total market in Australia is small and the Commonwealth's requirements are an enormous slice of that market in some cases. It is very difficult for an Australian company to take up the total amount of a contract. So one must encourage the Commonwealth purchasing area to have more than one Australian supplier available for a given product so that it can spread the risk-not only the risk to the Commonwealth of that supplier going out of business, but also the risk to the supplier of the Commonwealth changing its mind and leaving a supplier in the lurch. This will make tendering for the Commonwealth a lot more attractive.

Provisions have been made in government purchasing practice to take account of some of these difficulties. There is already in place a buy Australian policy for government purchasing, with guidelines. The policy is patently not working, nor is there any centralised monitoring of the procedures involved. I have tried to get statistics on this through questions on Estimates committees, direct questions and questions on notice. Basically, I have not been able to obtain any sensible, comprehensive up-to-date statistics on the buying patterns in the various departments, despite continued questions at Estimates committees.

The major problem with these current guidelines is that they are guidelines and they are co-ordinated through the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. This really produces some problems for the individual departments in terms of buying the particular product that they need. The recent problems with the computer purchasing for the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, which was the subject of a report from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, is testimony to this. The measure that we have currently in place, the Australian preference policy, states that a leeway of 20 per cent is available for public servants to call upon to justify why they have bought Australian. But that is the wrong way round. There is also the notional duty policy which is in place, and the offsets program which has worked to some extent in trying to bring industry into Australia. But, basically, what it does is bring label engineering exercises into Australia.

I will explain about label engineering. Computer companies bring in computers from overseas, put them through a factory, change the label on them and put up the price by 50 per cent. This does not involve any transfer of technology; it does not bring us into the area of having our own industry. The offsets program in this and in the motor car industry has basically not worked effectively. There has also been a system of pre-tender assistance that has worked slightly better in organisations such as Telecom Australia and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. I will talk about that a little later in this presentation.

However, we still have a major problem. That problem is known as dumping. Since overseas suppliers are prepared at times to sell at any price to get into the Australian market, and specifically into the Commonwealth market which gives them a leg in for private industry, it is sometimes insufficient just to have the 20 per cent minimum price advantage for Australian firms. What is more, if the overall actual difference would result in an extra cost to the taxpayer of $200,000 or more, Ministers have the discretion to decide whether the margin should apply. So the 20 per cent is not a real 20 per cent. If Ministers do not want to spend the money, they will agree to export the jobs.

I believe Ministers should review all purchases valued at more than $100,000 where preference margins still do not give the contract offer to the highest Australian content. We should reverse the onus. We should actually be saying: `Why are you buying overseas?' Instead we say: `Why are you buying Australian?'. In these circumstances the Minister has the authority still to accept the highest Australian content tender on the advice of an interdepartmental committee. However, the very centralisation of Commonwealth purchasing favours overseas suppliers which already have large market outlets and to which the Commonwealth contract is relatively small beer, although they are prepared to cut down their price for the prestige of a successful tender. Thus, while it is to the advantage of the taxpayer that the Commonwealth buy at the lowest possible price, in practice this means that the Commonwealth buys from overseas suppliers rather than from Australian suppliers. That means basically that we are getting into more and more foreign debt. In consequence, Australian suppliers are at a considerable disadvantage should they wish to expand production for export.

Most countries throughout the world operate preferential purchasing schemes whereby local suppliers are given preference over overseas suppliers if they can supply at all-not just this arbitrary 20 per cent rule. If an Australian company tries to export without being able to cite Australian Government contracts, it is assumed that that company has not been able to meet the Australian Government's standard and therefore it is not considered a good risk in a lot of countries where this particular preference policy operates. It is very difficult to break into those markets because people do not realise that our Government does not really give any preference to local purchase. It is for the same reason that overseas suppliers find Australian Government contracts sufficiently prestigious for them to be prepared to cut their price and dump their product on our market.

Since it is assumed that Australia operates a preferential buying system for Australian manufacturers, the overseas supplier to the Australian Government is assumed to have something that is much better than the local manufacturers, and hence the overseas supplier gets more kudos in its own country. Again, just because we are not willing to take into account the psychology of other people's markets, we are disadvantaging local suppliers. This is a real problem.

Australia in fact loses from the centralised buying policy in two ways. Firstly, our local industry loses a considerable local market share to overseas competitors and it is even further disadvantaged by the small size of the home market which is available to them in Australia. The volume advantage of supplying to the Government is lost because of the lack of security of government contracts. This means that a lot of the local manufacturers do not go for that particular option. Secondly, our trade balance suffers in two ways. It suffers, first, directly through payment from the Australian Government for its purchases overseas, which increases our total imports and, secondly, because of the disadvantage of Australian exporters who are competing for orders with a slur against their name because they have not been able to get government contracts, even though they have quoted for them. We must match the types of terms and conditions that exist inside other countries with which we compete.

Let us look at our current trade balance and compare it with government purchasing overseas. I would like to add at this point that, while we have been able to define very closely what Australia's overall imports and exports are and the exact trade deficit, it has proved almost impossible to obtain similar statistics on government purchasing. The estimates of the total government purchases last year varied from $5,000m to $8,000m. I would assume that the higher figure is correct, as this seems likely in view of the uncertainty and the fact that I can assume that the lower figure is incomplete. When trying to obtain estimates of how much of this amount was attributable to imports, we again have even more uncertainty. It seems that a few departments supply their figures only to the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services, which manages the centralised system. There is absolutely no monitoring by DOLGAS of this overseas content-or at least there is no reporting of it in a form that is available to parliamentarians, even on considerable probing. It seems probable that the Australian content is usually considered to be irrelevant in assessing tenders and therefore that the information is not of primary importance. This, again, suggests that the guidelines are not being followed.

The Department of Defence and the Department of Communications and its satellites are apparently the largest of our overseas buyers. DOLGAS reports that the Department of Defence and Telecom Australia together account for around 70 per cent of total government imports and that around 30 per cent of total government purchases are sourced from overseas. From this we can deduce-although with how much accuracy no one can be sure-that last year the Government imported around $2.4 billion worth of goods and services. Of course, a lot of this amount may be attributed to defence contracts which could not be met locally. But at least it would be nice to be able to get this information in the form of sensible statistics.

The total retail sales last year amounted to $52 billion. Government purchasing represents 15 per cent of retail sales in the whole of Australia. The total imports last year amounted to $35,616m. Government imported purchases amounted to around $2.4 billion, or approximately 7 per cent. That is only an estimated figure, because of the reasons I have given. The trade deficit last year amounted to $3.3 billion. Government purchases overseas amounted to 73 per cent of this total trade deficit. Thus, it is obvious that a much more positive buy Australian requirement on the Commonwealth Public Service could have a considerable effect on the Australian economy overall. Assuming that we could halve the Government's purchases of imported goods, this would result in a lowering of our trade deficit by more than one-third. Of course, increased Australian purchases in the equipment field will not necessarily decrease our imports by the same amount. Australia has almost no components industries, so that the Australian content of Australian manufactured equipment is in fact fairly low. Taking this into account, the total Australian content purchased by the Commonwealth can be seen as pretty low. We have to move out of this particular trap. We must take some technologies, develop components industries, develop such technologies from their infancy through all the stages that are necessary and then get the Australian private sector to co-operate with the public sector in developing ideas and moving ourselves into new areas of technology in which we can beat the world. Unless we do this in a few areas we will just become the type of banana republic which our Treasurer (Mr Keating) has said we already are.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has made us.

—Yes, which the Treasurer has made us. Our major difficulty is that we are not really tackling the problem. We have materials scientists who have some magnificent ideas, such as partially stabilised zirconia.
—Such as what?

—Partially stabilised zirconia, which has been developed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Division of Material Science. It is a type of ceramic which has some very interesting properties, both structurally and electrically.
—Bathroom tiles.

—Bathroom tiles that can pump oxygen in and out if electrical potential is put across the surface. I believe that such exciting ideas should be developed and handled. We should take those ideas and hand them over to local industries-not just to branch offices of foreign companies-and develop them over time. Again, we have some magnificent ideas that have been developed locally, such as the Winnin project. That is a decoy system that has been developed at the Defence Research Centre in my own State of South Australia. Out of this project can come a number of technologies that can be extremely useful in other areas. Also, we can make money exporting that type of decoy to countries that wish to acquire protection against Exocet missiles and the like. I believe that we should get involved, as was intended with that project, with a local manufacturer and produce the item locally, and then the Government should get involved in promoting the export industry that is associated with it. We have got to be more imaginative in the way we use our industries. We must use our purchasing power to produce an industrial base on which to build an export industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's policy seems to be based on offsets and many offset commitments are still unfulfilled. A thorough review of the offsets program is required and the Bill's provisions will ensure that offset programs will be examined at the outset instead of after the proposals have been made. I draw attention to the 1984 efficiency audits of the administration of the offsets policy and the administration of the Australian industry participation program on overseas procurement. The Government has tightened up since then, but the problem was often attitudinal and it is doubtful that these attitudes can be changed overnight, especially if no encouragement is given to public servants. This Bill gives encouragement to public servants to buy Australian. The Audit Office identified major shortcomings in all aspects of the offsets project, yet we still cannot be sure that anything has come forward in the form of effective remedial proposals. Policy guidelines were very unclear and created uncertainty and inconsistency in interpretation of significant purchases, and this led to a number of problems.

There was little evidence of comprehensive examination of offsets proposals. There were substantial shortcomings in the recording, monitoring and reporting of offset obligations, and in their fulfilment. Basically, the system was a bit of a charade and there was neither the administrative nor the political will to make sure that obligations were properly assessed and chased up. For instance, the Audit Office found during a limited study that contacts involving more than $176m had not been recorded for offsets considerations. The mind boggles at how much was lost to Australian industry because proper resources and procedures were not used to monitor offsets. No real effort was put into trying to make the offsets program work. There was an almighty shambles over the Leopard tank episode, which led to a large number of continuing problems.

In defence, only $300m of the $1,600m spent on major projects last year was spent in Australia. This information was provided six months after the question was taken on notice in Estimates Committee E in April. On top of the $300m, there is some flow-back because of offset obligation and other placement orders in Australia by overseas equipment manufacturers, but again we could not get any type of assessment. Of expenditure last year on the specific line item for weapons, armaments, ammunition and explosives, 65 per cent of the orders were placed with the Government Factories, 3 per cent with private Australian contractors, and 32 per cent with overseas sources. Again this information was produced six months after the relevant Estimates Committee had finished sitting and had reported. I commend the `Buy Australian' Bill. Basically I am suggesting that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) should be asked to draft a Bill based on the criteria set out in my motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Sessional Order of 22 February 1985 relating to the consideration of Government papers be amended by adding after paragraph (2) the following new paragraph:

``(2a) Where a statement by a Minister is presented and a motion is moved to take note of that statement in accordance with paragraph (1), the time taken by debate on that motion shall be disregarded for the purpose of the limitation of time provided by paragraph 2 (b).''

The motion is aimed at making certain that the type of manipulation of the Senate Notice Paper in which the Government has been indulging recently does not happen in future. The Australian Democrats have discussed this matter at some length with members of the Opposition, and I would like to bring to the notice of the Senate the provocation that led to this motion. Since I started looking at this problem, on 13 February this year, I have discovered 17 occasions on which ministerial statements have been given first, second or another place on the list of papers. Some were significant ministerial statements deserving of a lot more discussion than they received-discussion that they would have been given if they had been debated in government time. However, the time for discussion of government papers allows five minutes' debate per senator.

I believe that the Notice Paper has been somewhat manipulated through this technique and that senators have been asked to debate a number of issues in a much shorter time, and in a much less constructive way, than would have been the case if ministerial statements had been brought down in the normal way. Virtually all of those statements were put at the beginning of the Notice Paper and have had the effect of masking off some very important statements, such as follow-ups of statements from the Auditor-General concerning various statutory bodies, and reports of very important organisations within the Public Service, which senators have not been able to debate because there has not been time to do so. Dear Senator Cooney,

Thank you for your letter of 10 October 1986, in which you have expressed concern about a strict liability imposed on members of Boards of ACT credit societies who contravene the provisions of section 14g of the ACT Co-operative Societies Ordinance, introduced by the Co-operative Societies (Amendment) Ordinance (No. 2) 1986 (No. 10 of 1986).

It appears that the interpretation of section 14 set out in your letter may have overlooked some parts of the new section 14g. Sub-sections 14g (1f) and (1g) place percentage value limits on credit societies' loans. However these do not operate to make directors of the society liable for a loss occasioned simply by a decline, after the advance is made, in the market value of land. Such a liability would not arise in any case, whether a decline in value or an initial overestimate, where the directors acted bona fide, and on a valuation given by an approved valuer within three months before the advance, in lending funds up to the prescribed maximum limit. This is because in these circumstances the `value' of the land of which sub-sections (1f) and (1g) speak is defined as the `value' given in the valuation report, not the actual value: see sub-section (1j).

The only circumstances in which a loss would be likely to involve liability under sub-section (1h) are where the directors acted without first obtaining a valuation report, or advanced more than the prescribed percentage of the value reported to them. In either case, even if the debt went bad immediately and completely, the directors would be liable for 10% at most, or, if mortgage insurance were obtained, 5% at most, of the loss.

I do not think it unreasonable to impose such a liability. There is no statutory reserve fund for credit societies in the ACT, and the Government is not their lender of last resort as in the case of banks. I consider, therefore, that strict controls on the management of credit societies are necessary to secure the paramount policy objective of the Co-operative Societies Ordinance, the protection of societies' members. Indeed, provisions similar to section 14g already apply to building societies in the ACT and to building societies and credit unions in New South Wales. I understand that these provisions are not considered too onerous by the directors of these institutions, and that the risk of loss to the institutions is avoided by mortgage insurance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I had hoped that we would have had a little more time to debate this very important Bill, the Trade Practices Amendment Bill. It sounds dry enough to begin with but in fact it is a Bill brought forward by the Australian Democrats, through Senator Haines, some years ago which is designed to give some recourse to people who are sold cars which are lemons. In other words, from time to time in the ordinary process of the manufacture of motor vehicles, cars come off the production line containing a large variety of faults. Very few people in the community have not had the experience, or do not have friends who have had the experience, of owning a car which through its guarantee phase caused interminable trouble, which was taken back to the agents again and again and then at the end of the guarantee phase was still a bad vehicle with which the owner had been lumbered.

SPEECH.PARA: The purchase of a new motor vehicle is an expensive business for the people of this country and the Democrats think it is time this Bill was brought to its conclusion. I am sorry we will not have time to debate it fully today. We should do what the Connecticut legislature in the United States has done and provide for a definite recourse so that when a major motor manufacturer, which after all would not be an organisation short of money, sells someone a lemon it should be required to do something about it. In the terms of Senator Haines's Bill manufacturers would be required to give these people a new car or make a payment of an amount equal to the transaction when the consumer first acquired it, possibly taking into account some depreciation, if on no less than four occasions an authorised service agent has been given the job of fixing some mistake in the car, something which is wrong with it, and that defect has not been satisfactorily remedied. That is the first condition. The second is when the vehicle has been out of service for more than 30 days, whether a continuous period or not, by reason of any defect or defects to which the warranty is applicable during its warranty phase. We think they are very reasonable propositions. It is something which the people of this country want, and which they have every right to require.

Unfortunately this country has produced in the past some of the worst, most expensive and dangerous motor vehicles in the world. Even now it is impossible to guarantee that an example of a good model will be a good machine because it takes only some sort of error or difficulty, or maybe even just one incompetent or inexperienced worker along the production line, to have a quantity of motor cars coming out with defects which cost the unfortunate new owners thousands of dollars after the guarantee has expired. At present they have no recourse whatsoever.

The Bill has another important function. While the present situation exists, the motor industry can afford to be lazy, it can afford to be incompetent and not care too much so that when these poor unfortunate people come back the agent can say with impunity that the cars all make that noise, that it does not make the noise when he drives it, that it will go away soon or that the owner should either change his driving habits or ignore it. That is not good enough and we feel the industry should be compelled not to allow it to happen. Those involved are not doing it voluntarily. It is essential that this Bill come on for debate again as soon as possible. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
